interactive.cheadline: 游戏改编剧能否比电影更好？《光环》给你答案
interactive.clongleadbody: 《光环》的改编电视剧的播出效果虽贬多赞少，但游戏改编成剧仍不失为影视行业的新方向。
interactive.cbody:
长期以来，《光环》（Halo）的主角士官长可以说是一个不讨喜的英雄角色。这是一个被定义成拥有无限力量且粗暴的人物，他的名字是两个听起来很生硬的头衔嫁接在一起的，直到最后他才被赋予了一个真正的人类名字，那就是，约翰(John)。玩家甚至从未见过他的正脸：因为他头盔上的琥珀色面罩从未打开过。 鉴于《光环》是一个用激光枪射击外星人的游戏，所以这并不是个问题。士官长形象的留白可以使玩家能够更容易地将自己带入到他的身份中。然而，对于派拉蒙影业(Paramount Plus)新改编的《光环》电视剧来说，这却是一个阻碍。游戏可以有有趣的人物和情节，但它们不一定依赖于此。电视剧则不然。在执行制片人史蒂文·斯皮尔伯格(Steven Spielberg)的指导下，派拉蒙影业需要做出改变。 首先，他们决定士官长必须露脸——由憨憨的巴勃罗·施雷伯饰演，从他在Netflix监狱喜剧剧情片《女子监狱》(Orange is the New Black)中扮演的 "Pornstache“一角中，可以看出演技提升了很多。然后，他们将16款游戏中的科幻故事整合成半连贯的故事，即人类与外星人之间的对抗，其中不乏大量无聊的对话。 值得表扬的是，他们通过在游戏中偶然提及的线索(如士官长的起初是一个童兵，14岁时在实验室中获得生物强化)，为这个世界注入了一些道德模糊感。他们还不断地套用游戏内容，包括能量剑、从士官长头盔中看到的第一人称视角，以及穿着隐形迷彩的外星人。总的来说，这部电视剧的效果很平庸，虽有娱乐性的打斗场面，和看得下去的情节转折(如果遵循原著的话)，但几乎没有太大的差别或新意。它不太可能吸引《光环》玩家之外的任何人。但鉴于全球游戏玩家近30亿，该剧还是有可能获得成功。并且第二季开拍已经获批了。
奈飞公司(Netflix)的《秘传》(Arcane)利用动画将游戏《英雄联盟》(League of Legends)中的金克丝等角色栩栩如生地呈现出来。
随着流媒体平台贪婪地收购有价值的科幻和幻想ip，特别是那些已经拥有大量年轻用户的游戏，《光环》只是众多被改编成剧的游戏中的一款。HBO即将推出僵尸巨作《最后的生还者》的改编版，《切尔诺贝利》(Chernobyl)的编剧克雷格·马辛(Craig Mazin)也将加盟。此外，根据叙事游戏《奇异人生》(Life is Strange)和《迪斯科天堂》(Disco Elysium)改编的电视剧也将登陆亚马逊平台。还有数十款游戏正在不同的制作阶段，包括最新的《生化危机》、《古墓丽影》、《刺客信条》以及《细胞分裂》和《辐射》。 从几十年糟糕的电影改编史中我们已经知道，游戏很难被改编成剧。但游戏真的在电视屏幕上更好地演绎出来吗？ 电影导演在将游戏改编成电影时似乎忽略了一点，即游戏并非围绕着我们所听到的故事，而是围绕着我们所居住的世界。他们需要搞明白，这个故事被观看而不是被播放意味着什么，以及它应该如何相应地做出改变。在这方面，电视剧可能是更自然的选择。电视剧的长度为多样化的游戏故事叙述风格，及其角色演绎创造了空间。这种改编余地有助于追求“构建世界”的潮流，也应该足以让节目制作人利用现代游戏中丰富的传说和环境细节。 两部为这种形式带来希望的电视节目都是动画。第一部是《恶魔城》，这是一部吸血鬼故事，改编自上世纪90年代的一系列热门游戏，自2017年上映以来，它在网飞上出人意料地火了起来。它的文笔犀利，主题成熟，情节缜密，为去年《秘传》的大火铺平了道路。网飞的另一部电视剧《秘传》，则采用融合了手绘纹理和3D图像做出惊人的动画，深入挖掘了在线战斗游戏《英雄联盟》中两位英雄的故事起源。与其他改编电影不同的是，《秘传》摒弃了繁琐的情节阐述，更倾向于以人物为导向的剧情，对原始材料松散地处理，专注于两个女人之间的复杂关系，只在对叙事有意义的地方加入改动。 这两款游戏所吸引的受众远远超出了游戏玩家的范畴。与《火线》(The Wire)、《绝命毒师》(Breaking Bad)和肯·伯恩斯(Ken Burns)的纪录片《越南战争》(The Vietnam War)一起，《秘传》甚至在IMDB有史以来收视率最高的25部电视节目中占据了一席之地。这是第一个真正伟大的游戏改编，但从未来要发行的电视改编剧数量来看，它不太可能会是最后的高光。
interactive.eheadline: Could TV shows based on games be better than films?
interactive.elongleadbody: An underwhelming new Halo series may be a harbinger for the many adaptations in the pipeline — but there is hope
interactive.ebody:
Longtime Halo protagonist Master Chief is a charmless hero. This is a character defined by limitless reserves of strength and gruffness, whose moniker is two tough-sounding titles grafted together (eventually he is given a real human name, which is — wait for it — John). Players have never even seen his face: the amber visor of his helmet stays resolutely closed. Given that Halo is a game about blasting aliens with laser guns, this has never been a problem. Chief’s blankness allows players to project themselves more easily into his reinforced boots. Yet it was a hurdle for the new Halo TV adaptation on Paramount Plus. Games can have interesting characters and plots, but they don’t necessarily depend on them. Not so with television. Paramount, under the guidance of executive producer Steven Spielberg, needed to make changes. First, they decided Chief had to show his face — a gormless Pablo Schreiber, much beefed-up from his days as “Pornstache” in the Netflix prison comedy-drama Orange is the New Black. Then they crunched 16 games’ worth of sci-fi pabulum into a semi-coherent narrative that pits humans against aliens and involves much wooden dialogue. To the writing team’s credit, they do inject some moral ambiguity into the world by picking at threads only glancingly mentioned in the games (such as Master Chief’s origins as a child soldier, biologically enhanced in a lab at 14). They also cram in endless references to the games, including energy swords, first-person views from inside Chief’s helmet and aliens with invisibility camo. The overall result is distinctly mediocre TV, with entertaining fight scenes and effective, if predictable, plot twists, but little nuance or originality. It’s unlikely to appeal to anyone outside Halo’s gamer fan base. But with gamers numbering almost 3bn worldwide, that might be enough to make the show a success. A second season has already been greenlit.
Netflix’s ‘Arcane’ uses animation to bring to life characters such as Jinx from the game ‘League of Legends’
Halo is just one of a host of games being turned into series as streaming platforms voraciously buy up valuable sci-fi and fantasy IPs, particularly those that bring substantial pre-existing audiences with younger demographics. On the way are lavish adaptations of zombie masterpiece The Last of Us for HBO, with Chernobyl writer Craig Mazin attached, as well as shows based on narrative games Life is Strange and Disco Elysium, coming to Amazon. Dozens more are in various stages of production, including fresh iterations of Resident Evil, Tomb Raider and Assassin’s Creed as well as Splinter Cell and Fallout. We already know from decades of dreadful film adaptations that games can be tricky to adapt. Do they have a better chance on the small screen? What film directors seem to miss when adapting games for cinema is that games do not revolve around stories we are told but worlds we inhabit. They need to ask what it means for this story to be watched rather than played, and how it might have to change accordingly. In that respect, TV may prove a more natural fit. The length of a series creates space for the sprawling storytelling style of games and their myriad characters. This breathing room should also allow showrunners to capitalise on the abundant lore and environmental detail of modern games, which assist in the trendy pursuit of “world-building”. Two TV shows that offer hope for the form are both animations. The first is Castlevania, a vampire story based on a series of hit 1990s games, which has become a surprise hit on Netflix since launching in 2017. It is sharply written with mature themes and thoughtful plotting and paved the way for last year’s Arcane. Another Netflix show, Arcane digs into the origin stories of two heroes from the online battle arena game League of Legends using striking animation that blends hand-painted textures with 3D graphics. Unlike other adaptations, Arcane forgoes fussy plot exposition in favour of character-driven drama and plays loosely with its source material, focusing on the complex relationship between two women and including action only where it meaningfully impacts the narrative. Both have charmed audiences far beyond the world of gamers. Arcane has even earned a place in IMDB’s list of the highest-rated 25 TV shows of all time, in the company of The Wire, Breaking Bad and Ken Burns’s docu-series The Vietnam War. It is the first truly great gaming adaptation but, judging by the sheer quantity of series to come, it is unlikely to be the last.

interactive.cheadline: 绿色之旅：一起乘上09:02从伦敦出发的乡村花园快车
interactive.clongleadbody: 抛开汽车，来一次一流的火车旅行，沉浸探索绿色的庄园兼田园：位于萨默塞特的纽特。
interactive.cbody:
本文属于伦敦指南来自FT Globetrotter 去年，我家放弃了生锈的汽车，试图减少维修和停车的费用--以及减少我们对气候变化的影响。利用伦敦的公共汽车、地铁和出租车，在伦敦四处游玩已经很方便了。但是，不受背包束缚的时尚乡村旅行会是怎么样的呢？ “在纽特庄园度假酒店躲避喧嚣”(The Newt’s Great Garden Escape)为我渴望呼吸新鲜空气提供了一个豪华的解决方案，包括前往萨默塞特乡村的铁路旅行，参观酒店的大花园、包含三道菜的午餐以及品尝酒店酿造的苹果酒。
英国铁路公司宣传萨默塞特的复古海报
这个套餐是在疫情封锁前推出的，但在去年夏天随着防疫措施放宽才正式启用，那些在城市里被关疯的人把积攒下来的钱花在了修剪整齐的乡村田园上。 作为一个无畏的旅行者，我报名参加了。在一个阳光明媚的日子里，我来到帕丁顿车站(Paddington station)的头等舱休息室，在车站工作人员的护送下上了火车，并得到了一份早餐（薄脆的羊角面包、上好的黄油、格兰诺拉麦片、火腿和橙汁），然后乘坐短途客车从格拉斯顿伯里附近的卡里城堡车站(Castle Cary station)前往布鲁顿的纽特庭院。萨默塞特的这一地区已经成为新的奇平诺顿(Chipping Norton)，或诺丁山(Notting Hill)，或一些类似的小资中心。居民包括前财政大臣乔治•奥斯本(George Osborne)、时装设计师斯特拉•麦卡特尼(Stella McCartney)和戏剧制作人卡梅隆•麦金托什(Cameron Mackintosh)。

这个庄园可以追溯到17世纪

位于萨默塞特的纽特庄园占地800英亩，由林地和农田组成。
Dook照片(2) 这座房子是霍布豪斯家族的祖先所在地，其家族成员包括商人、地主和自由党政治家，其中阿瑟•霍布豪斯(Arthur Hobhouse)不仅是布鲁姆斯伯里集团(Bloomsbury set)中几位成员的情人，最著名的是艺术家邓肯•格兰特(Duncan Grant)，而且后来还成为该国国家公园的建筑师。他的儿媳妇佩内洛普•霍布豪斯(Penelope Hobhouse)是一位作家兼园丁，她监督了庄园花园的建设，并将其向公众开放。 如今，这座庄园的所有者是Elle Decoration前南非版编辑卡伦•鲁斯(Karen Roos)和她的丈夫库斯•贝克(Koos Bekker)，他是一位亿万富翁商人、和媒体公司Naspers董事长。这对夫妇还在南非的Cape winlands拥有巴比伦商店，并于2013年买下了这处萨默塞特郡的房产，花了6年时间装修。
花园咖啡馆，提供的食物都是在庄园或周围地区饲养或种植的。
参观的重点是这处占地800英亩的庄园，这里的农田里也有牲畜(英国白牛和蓝德缅因羊，餐厅里皆有供应)、花园、果园和古老的林地，果园里种着70种苹果。这个花园本身就是一个旅游目的地，一个卖果酱、苹果酒和肉的商店，以及一个餐厅。 上午，园长斯蒂芬•赫林顿(Stephen Herrington)带领来自伦敦的团队参观，穿过树林看红鹿和黇鹿以及日式围墙花园。庄园由40名园丁监管，负责照料蔬菜、沙拉和草药，以及古老的林地和观赏性植物。 在离酒店不远的山坡上一家通风良好、正面是玻璃的餐厅里吃午饭，感觉棒极了。所有的盘子里都有自家种植或从庄园里采集的食物，其余的食材都是从附近的农场采购的。蔬菜是这里的主角。开胃菜是巴勃罗红葡萄酒、欧当归、苹果和洋葱籽，肥美的芦笋配上刺山柑和龙蒿。主菜是烤花椰菜，配以发酵的叶子和杏仁酸奶，还有一份烤羊肉。布丁上有甜得恰到好处的梅子和水牛乳冰淇淋。
有机打理的纽特厨房花园。
蔬菜是纽特花园咖啡馆的主角，大部分农产品都是现场种植或采摘的。
纽特非常重视其可持续发展倡议，例如种植餐厅所需食物，避免对农场牲畜使用现代杀虫剂和合成虫。它采用有机原理，比如不挖土，因为挖土会破坏其结构。午饭后，我们在院子里四处走走，为等会的品尝留出些肚子：由酒窖大师格雷格•卡内尔(Greg Carnell)主持的苹果酒品尝会。我曾经因为喝了太多Appletiser吐过一次(说真的)，我对苹果饮料已经有几十年的厌恶了，所以我是怀着恐惧的心情来参加这个活动。 庄园的苹果酒窖使用来自庄园果园和周边地区的苹果汁，不添加糖或水，采用冷发酵方法。近四年的时间里，该庄园已经生产了近100万瓶苹果酒，在商店和线上销售。这场活动让我大开眼界。这些酒中，我最喜欢喝上等的起泡苹果酒，它的起泡度和干度就像香槟一样，还有甜布丁苹果酒--是苏特恩白葡萄酒的良好替代品。

苹果酒窖提供的产品，如这款rosé，采用冷发酵方法制成，不添加糖或水

庄园内种植了70多个品种的苹果

然后我们被送上返回伦敦的火车，侍者给了我们盒装的奶油茶，里面还有葡萄酒、苹果酒或茶(那时不多)，应有尽有。旅行一天需要335英镑，这太贵了。尽管有两位细心的导游照顾我们，但就这个价格而言，我希望能得到的是餐盘而不是野餐盒，还有去酒店体验的机会。不过，这个套餐包括一年的纽特会员资格，可以无限制地进入花园，而进入花园费用通常为68英镑，本地人为30英镑(16岁以下免费)。行程排得满满的，没有多少时间可以自由活动，所以我会等到花园盛开的时候再次回来。 艾玛·雅各布斯(Emma Jacobs)是纽特的客人。 于萨默塞特的“在纽特大花园度假酒店躲避喧嚣”套餐价格为成人335英镑，儿童260英镑(5至15岁)，每周五和周六举办，直到2022年9月。门票可购于thenewtinsomerset.com/great-garden-escape 你在伦敦及其周边地区有什么绿色度假活动可以推荐吗？请在评论中告诉我们 在Instagram上关注FT Globetrotter@FTGlobetrotter

interactive.eheadline: Greener getaways: all aboard the 09:02 Country Garden Express from London
interactive.elongleadbody: Leave the car behind for a first-class train journey whose destination is a day of indulgence and exploration on a sustainable estate-cum-pastoral idyll: The Newt in Somerset
interactive.ebody:
This article is part of a guide to London from FT Globetrotter Last year, my family ditched our rusty car in an attempt to cut the costs of maintenance and parking — as well as reduce our impact on climate change. It’s easy enough to get around London, with its network of buses, Tubes and taxis. But what about travelling to the countryside in style, unfettered by rucksacks? The Newt’s Great Garden Escape offered a luxurious solution to my hankering for fresh air, providing a rail trip to the Somerset countryside, as well as tour of the hotel’s vast gardens, three-course lunch and a tasting of ciders made in the grounds.
A vintage British Railways poster advertising Somerset
This package was launched before lockdowns but took off last summer, as Covid restrictions loosened and those going stir crazy in the city splashed pent-up savings on stays at a manicured rural idyll. Ever the intrepid traveller, I signed up. On a crisp sunny day, I made my way to the first-class lounge at Paddington station, escorted to the train by staff from the station, and issued with a breakfast picnic (flaky croissant, excellent butter, granola, ham and orange juice), and then on a short coach trip from Castle Cary station, near Glastonbury, to the Newt’s grounds in Bruton. This area of Somerset has become the new Chipping Norton, or Notting Hill, or some such centre of bougie, with residents including the ex-chancellor George Osborne, fashion designer Stella McCartney and Cameron Mackintosh, the theatre producer.

The estate dates back to the 17th century

The Newt in Somerset’s 800 acres are a mix of woodland and farmland

Dook Photo (2)
The Newt, a kind of concept country estate, is not far from the original glamour country hotel Babington House, the rural outpost of Soho House, and the stage for many society and celebrity weddings. My day trip sadly did not include a visit to the actual hotel, which occupies the 17th-century Hadspen House (which was remodelled in the 18th century) and a former dairy, and starts at £385 a night. The house is the ancestral seat of the Hobhouse family, whose lineage included merchants, landowners and Liberal politicians, including Arthur Hobhouse, who was not only the lover of various members of the Bloomsbury set, notably artist Duncan Grant, but later the architect of the country’s national parks. His daughter-in-law Penelope Hobhouse, the writer and gardener, oversaw the development of the estate’s gardens, opening them to the public. Today the estate is owned by Karen Roos, the former South Africa Elle Decoration editor, and her husband Koos Bekker, the billionaire businessman and chair of media company Naspers. The couple also own Babylonstoren in South Africa’s Cape Winelands, and bought the Somerset property in 2013, spending six years doing it up.
The Garden Café, where the food served is reared, grown or foraged on the estate or its environs
The focus of the visit is the estate’s 800 acres, a mix of farmland with livestock (British White cattle and Bleu de Maine sheep, which are served in their restaurants), gardens, orchards with 70 varieties of apple and ancient woodland. This garden is a destination itself offering tours, a shop with jams, cider and meat, as well as a restaurant. In the morning, the group from London was given a tour by Stephen Herrington, the head gardener, including through the woods to see the red and fallow deer and the Japanese and walled gardens. The estate is overseen by 40 gardeners tending to vegetables, salad and herbs, as well as the ancient woodland, and ornamental planting. Lunch in the airy, glass-fronted restaurant perched on a hillside some way from the hotel, was excellent. All the plates include something grown or foraged from the estate, and remaining ingredients are sourced from neighbouring farms. Vegetables are the star of the show. Starters were crushed Pablo red, lovage, apple and onion seeds with fat asparagus garnished with capers and tarragon. While the main was a roast spiced cauliflower, with fermented leaves and almond yoghurt and a side of chargrilled lamb. For pudding there were perfectly sweetened plums and buffalo-milk ice cream.
The Newt’s kitchen garden, which is tended organically
Vegetables are the star of the show at The Newt’s Garden Cafe, and much of the produce is grown or foraged on site
The Newt makes much play of its sustainable initiatives such as growing food used in the kitchen and avoiding modern pesticides and synthetic wormers in the farm’s livestock. It uses organic principles, such as not digging soil, which ruins its structure. After lunch, we were given a much-needed opportunity to walk around the grounds and create some room for the next step of the day: a cider-tasting session led by Greg Carnell, the cellar master. Having thrown up once after too much Appletiser (seriously), I have a decades-long aversion to apple drinks, so I approached this with trepidation. The estate’s Cyder Cellar uses apple juice from the estate’s orchards and surrounding areas, with no added sugar or water, deploying a cold- fermentation method. In almost four years, the estate has produced almost 1mn bottles, which it sells in the shop and online. It was a revelation. I most enjoyed the fine sparkling cider, which was like a champagne in fizziness and dryness, and the sweet pudding cider — a good substitute for Sauternes.

The Cyder Cellar’s offerings — such as this rosé — are made using a cold-fermentation method, with no added sugar or water

More than 70 varieties of apple are grown on the estate

Then we were whisked to the returning train to London, served a cream tea in boxes with as much wine, cider or tea as we wanted (not much by then). For a day, £335 is steep. And although we were looked after by two attentive tour guides, for that price I would have expected plates rather than a picnic box, and access to the hotel. However, it includes a year’s Newt membership, which includes unlimited entry to the gardens and usually costs £68, or £30 to locals (under-16s go free). The packed itinerary did not allow much free time to go roaming, so I would return when the gardens are in full bloom. Emma Jacobs was a guest of the Newt. The Great Garden Escape to The Newt in Somerset is priced at £335 per adult, £260 per child (ages five to 15) and runs on Fridays and Saturdays until September 2022. interactive.cheadline: 五种有益健康的小玩意
interactive.clongleadbody: 从可持续空气过滤器到防蓝光眼镜，这些小发明会让你感觉更好。
interactive.cbody:
肺部游戏 在我旁边的桌子上，一个透明的罐子轻轻地嗡嗡作响，里面装满了郁郁葱葱的微型森林，呼出的是北极般洁净的、令人平静的空气。我的绿色小伙伴——基本上是一个充满活力的玻璃容器——据说是世界上“最可持续”的空气过滤器。这款优雅的新产品来自利兹的两位工程师，使用了美国宇航局(NASA)以前在宇宙飞船上使用的空气过滤技术。它的主要成分是驯鹿苔，一种海绵状地衣(一种藻类-真菌的混合物)，擅长吸收污染物。它还含有椰壳纤维(另一种常用在汽车行业的优良天然过滤器)，活性炭(用于捕获微尘)和生物塑料外壳。再加个风扇让一切运转起来。

仅仅看一眼它就会让我感觉更健康。

Briiv比水壶还小，但创造了一个没有有毒气体、霉菌、细菌、花粉和其他有害物质的小绿洲：测试表明，它在短短一个小时内有效地改善了36平方米房间的空气质量。它可以手动操作，也可以通过应用程序操作，这样你就可以对它进行安排，并控制强度。考虑到伦敦市长萨迪克·汗最近18个月来首次发布“高污染警告”，以及全球污染水平在疫情封锁期间普遍下降后再次回升，这似乎是一个清理小空间的及时解决办法。显然，它对空气的净化作用与3043盆室内植物相同。我会让你决定什么对你的家更有意义。
Briiv空气过滤器，299英镑
绿色环保特性使Briiv与充斥市场的重塑料HEPA空气过滤器区分开来：96%的设备是可生物降解或可回收的。(苔藓会在几个月内分解，椰子壳会在一年内分解;你可以订购替换零件。)坦白地说，它看起来也很可爱。不管它对我的肺有什么好处，只要看一眼它就会让我觉得更健康，就好像我在伦敦东部的公寓里有一片充满生命活力的北方森林。Briiv空气过滤器，售价299英镑，Briiv .co.uk。 避开蓝光
Bollé Safety ProBlu眼镜，72英镑起
鉴于智能手机、电视和电脑屏幕发出的光亮与眼睛干涩、睡眠不安等各种情况有关，戴防蓝光眼镜似乎是明智的。尽管这是否科学还并不清晰，但粉丝们说它们能防止你在打字一天后出现头痛和眼睛疲劳。而且有证据表明，如果你在晚上戴着它们，会睡得更好。为此，法国护目镜制造商Bollé Safety推出了一系列规格。由于采用聚碳酸酯镜片和防反射镜片涂层，这些眼镜可以100%阻挡波长为420纳米的有害蓝光，82%阻挡波长为380纳米至445纳米的有害蓝光。此外，它们构造良好，外观漂亮。Bollé Safety ProBlu眼镜，72英镑起，Bolle-safety.com 心的问题
AliveCor KardiaMobile, 99英镑起
AliveCor的口袋型心电图设备为个人提供医疗级的心率和心律检测。型号包括KardiaMobile，一个有两个银色垫子的长方形设备；以及新的KardiaMobile卡（目前仅限美国），一个类似运通卡的薄片。用户将手指按在设备上，结果显示在应用程序上。该应用程序（如果订阅了KardiaCare）应用人工智能生成算法，对六种类型的心律失常发出警报。这些设备已经获得了美国食品和药物管理局的批准。今年，英国NICE推荐在英国国家医疗服务体系(NHS)中使用KardiaMobile。AliveCor KardiaMobile，99英镑起（外加99英镑的KardiaCare）；KardiaMobile卡，149美元（包括KardiaCare）。 豪雅健身
豪雅Connected Calibre E4手表，1550英镑起
虽然没有我平时的训练营教练那么可怕，但智能手表正在指导我进行核心训练。我的腹肌在燃烧，正如屏幕上的追踪器显示的那样，我的心跳在加速。豪雅表(TAG Heuer)推出了新款联网手表Calibre E4，吸引了那些原本可能转而购买苹果手表的消费者。除了提供对跑步、骑自行车、打高尔夫球和游泳的跟踪功能，一项新功能还提供了7分钟的锻炼。这款手表给人一种高端但不失运动的感觉。它有华丽的不锈钢表壳，可供选择的动画表盘和各种表带。两次充电之间的间隔时间应该可以持续一整天，而且如果你的手表在几年后开始抖动，还有电池更换服务。TAG Heuer Connected Calibre E4手表，1550英镑起，tagheuer.com 站立和释放
BBalance Matscale, 349美元
还有什么比踩到浴室体重计更让人不爽吗？法国BBalance公司提供了一种玻璃平板的替代品，将我们的健康仅仅归结为公斤和磅数。该公司设计了一种智能浴垫，在其柔软的棉质外衣下装有4000多个传感器和电极。根据你的足迹——并与一款应用程序同步——它可以确定身体脂肪百分比和肌肉质量，并对姿势、平衡和理想的鞋码做出规定。扁平足或高足弓？它也会告诉你。它建议通过锻炼来解决问题，比如单腿运动来提高平衡或拉直姿势。现在可以预订，今年夏天发货。BBalance Matscale, 349美元，bbalance.io @jamie_waters
interactive.eheadline: Five great health-boosting gadgets
interactive.elongleadbody: From a sustainable air filter to blue-light-blocking glasses, these gizmos will make you feel better
interactive.ebody:
The lung game A clear jar filled with a miniature forest of lush lichen is gently whirring on the table next to me, exhaling Arctic-clean air and an air of calm. My little green companion – basically a terrarium with oomph – is purportedly the world’s “most sustainable” air filter. An elegant new creation from a pair of Leeds-based engineers who applied air-filtration technologies formerly used by NASA in spaceships, its star ingredient is reindeer moss, a spongy lichen (an algae-fungus hybrid) that’s great at hoovering up pollutants. It also contains coconut-husk fibres (another decent natural filter often used in the car industry), activated carbon (for capturing fine dust) and a bioplastic casing. Plus a fan to keep things moving.

Merely glancing at it makes me feel healthier

No bigger than a kettle, Briiv creates a little oasis of air free of toxic gases, mould, bacteria, pollen and other nasties: tests show that it effectively improves the air quality in a 36sq m room in just an hour. It’s operated manually or via an app, which enables you to put it on a schedule and control its intensity. Given that London mayor Sadiq Khan recently issued a “high pollution warning” for the first time in 18 months – and global pollution levels are picking up again after a general dip during pandemic lockdowns – it seems a timely fix to clean up a small space. Apparently it has the same air-scrubbing impact as 3,043 houseplants. I’ll let you decide what makes more sense for your home.
Briiv air filter, £299
Briiv’s green-ness separates it from the plastic-heavy HEPA air filters flooding the market: 96 per cent of the device is biodegradable or recyclable. (The moss will decompose in a few months and the coconut husks in up to a year; you can order replacement parts.) Frankly, it’s also just a lovely thing to look at. Irrespective of the good it’s actually doing to my lungs, merely glancing at it makes me feel healthier, as though there’s a life-affirming chunk of boreal forest in my east London flat. Briiv air filter, £299, briiv.co.uk
Beat the blue light
Bollé Safety ProBlu glasses, from £72
Given that the glow emitted by smartphones, TVs and computer screens has been linked to everything from dry eyes to restless sleep, blue- light-blocking glasses seem sensible. Though the science is not crystal clear, fans say they stop you getting headaches and tired eyes after a day spent typing. And there’s evidence suggesting that, if you wear them in the evening, they help you sleep better. To that end French goggle maker Bollé Safety has launched a line of specs that, thanks to polycarbonate lenses and an anti-reflective lens coating, block 100 per cent of harmful blue light up to wavelengths of 420nm and 82 per cent beyond that (harmful ranges from 380nm to 445nm). They’re well built and good looking. Bollé Safety ProBlu glasses, from £72, bolle-safety.com
Heart of the matter
AliveCor KardiaMobile, from £99
AliveCor’s pocket-sized ECG devices provide individuals with medical-grade readings of heart rates and rhythms. Models include the KardiaMobile, a rectangle with two silver pads; and (currently US only) the new KardiaMobile Card, an Amex-like sliver. Users press their fingers to the devices; the results are displayed on the app that (with a KardiaCare subscription) applies an AI-generated algorithm to alert you to the possibility of six types of arrhythmia. The gadgets have been approved by the FDA and, this year, the UK’s NICE recommended the KardiaMobile for use within the NHS. AliveCor KardiaMobile, from £99 (plus £99 KardiaCare); KardiaMobile Card, $149 (including KardiaCare)
Workout by the Heuer
TAG Heuer Connected Calibre E4 watch, from £1,550
While less fearsome than my usual bootcamp instructor, a smartwatch is guiding me through my core workout. My abs are burning and – as an on-screen tracker shows – my heart is racing. With its new Connected Calibre E4, TAG Heuer is wooing those who might otherwise turn to an Apple Watch. As well as providing tracking for running, cycling, golfing and swimming, a new feature offers seven-minute workouts. The watch has a premium yet sporty feel, with a gorgeous stainless-steel case, a choice of animated faces and various straps. It should last a full day between charges and there’s a new battery replacement service should your watch start to wobble in a few years’ time. TAG Heuer Connected Calibre E4 watch, from £1,550, tagheuer.com
Stand and deliver
BBalance Matscale, ¢349
Is anything more joyless than stepping onto a bathroom scale? French company BBalance is offering an alternative to slabs of glass that reduce our health solely to kilos and pounds. It has devised a smart bath mat that houses more than 4,000 sensors and electrodes beneath its soft cotton coat. Based on your footprint – and in sync with an app – it determines body fat percentage and muscle mass and makes rulings on posture, balance and ideal shoe size. Flat-footed or high arches? It’ll tell you that too. It recommends exercises to address concerns, such as one-legged movements to improve balance or straighten your stance. Available to preorder now, it ships this summer. BBalance Matscale, $349, bbalance.io @jamie_waters

interactive.cheadline: 为电动汽车提供动力：在美国本土开采锂的竞赛
interactive.clongleadbody: 北卡罗来纳州农村的一家矿业公司的经验表明，美国的锂业要取代中国的主导地位，并非易事。
interactive.cbody:
在他位于北卡罗来纳州皮埃蒙特乡村地区卡托巴河附近的红砖小农舍里，布莱恩·哈珀(Brian Harper)因美国大力推动绿色能源未来而陷入困境。 美国最大的锂辉石矿位于靠近哈珀的土地下方的带状地带，这种矿物可以通过加工提取锂，锂对制造用于电动汽车的可充电电池至关重要。 看到这一快速增长地区的商机，最初在澳大利亚成立的矿业公司皮埃蒙特锂业(Piedmont Lithium)几年前就开始敲开约3000英亩土地周围的老房子的门，提出购买土地，以便开始钻探大型矿坑以提取矿物。 由于国际能源署预测未来几年的需求量将大大超过计划的供应量，皮埃蒙特公司在获得所有必要的采矿许可证之前，就毫不犹豫地承诺向美国的电动汽车公司特斯拉(Tesla)销售锂。 但是，尽管皮埃蒙特锂业已经成功地买下了一些地块，但它遇到了许多潜在的新邻居的坚决反对，其中包括哈珀，他经营着一家为工业机械制造齿轮的小企业，就在离拟议的新矿场不远的地方。
皮埃蒙特锂业公司在加斯顿县贝尔蒙特的办公室。该公司遭到了其拟议铜矿附近许多潜在新邻居的坚决反对
“当他们开始爆破，地面开始震动时，我的机器就不可能正常工作了，”哈珀说。哈珀在他的前花园里树立了一个小小的纠察牌，上面有一个红色的停止标志，字体很大，在“加斯顿县矿井”这几个字上面划了一条大大的红线。 接受《金融时报》采访的其他人认为，像皮埃蒙特公司提议的这种规模的硬岩矿会造成光、噪音和灰尘污染，并使他们的水源受到有毒径流物质的污染。 拟建矿区周围的许多房屋没有连接到市政供水系统，而是从井中提取饮用水，这就加剧了人们的担忧，即矿区的任何意外径流或地下水污染会毒害他们的水源。 皮埃蒙特锂业表示，该公司已经制定了“若干”噪音和粉尘缓解计划，包括限制使用卡车的数量。它承诺不让危险的水进入地表水溪流、小河和地下水，并监测当地水井的水量和质量。该公司说：“如果我们意识到当地水井的任何问题，将予以纠正。” 皮埃蒙特在公开会议上辩称，它的新矿将伴随一个加工厂，将为该地区带来新的就业机会。 但是，该公司计划推出几十年来第一个大型新锂矿之一，也是目前美国第二个正在运营的锂矿，已经落后于计划。该项目本应在2020年之前开工。截至2022年5月，它还没有申请到破土动工所需的所有许可证。 美国总统乔•拜登(Joe Biden)计划打造更绿色、更创新的经济，而美国电动汽车电池行业是该计划的核心，他的政府决心扩大绿色技术所依赖的国内矿产开采。3月底，它援引朝鲜战争时期的《国防生产法案》(Defense Production Act)，腾出更多资金，用于协助国内锂、钴、镍、石墨和锰的开采。
2021年11月，马西埃·帕特南和她的母亲凯茜在加斯顿县法院举行的皮埃蒙特锂矿公开听证会上查看地图
但对美国来说，锂或许代表着最大的机遇。国际能源署称，随着世界从石油和天然气向绿色能源电网转型，锂的需求增长最快。如果世界要实现《巴黎协定》设定的全球气候目标，到2040年，锂的需求量将至少是现在的40倍。 美国地质调查局(US Geological Survey)的数据显示，美国拥有约800万吨锂，是全球锂储量最大的五个国家之一。然而，美国开采和加工的产量仅占全球产量的1%。其余大部分来自中国、智利和澳大利亚。 随着美国试图在全球电池生产竞赛中取得领先，为绿色转型提供动力，华盛顿方面正鼓励皮埃蒙特等公司在美国本土动工建设更多采矿项目。但它也希望确保州监管机构、环保活动人士和当地社区不会被抛在后面。

竞争中的美国

专门研究锂离子电池数据的咨询公司Benchmark Mineral Intelligence首席执行官西蒙•摩尔斯(Simon Moores)表示，电动汽车市场的爆炸式增长引发了一场“电池军备竞赛”。 电池制造商将努力寻找制造电池所需的原始矿物，包括钴、镍、石墨和锂。然而，尽管科学家们在开发不需要钴或镍来运作的电池方面取得了早期的成功，但到目前为止，还没有找到任何摆脱锂的可能性。按照摩尔斯的说法，“锂是让行业感到恐惧的东西”。 国际能源署表示，全球80%以上的锂矿在澳大利亚、智利和中国开采，仅中国就控制了全球一半以上的加工和精炼。美国虽然在内华达州有一个未开采的锂矿，但主要从阿根廷和智利进口。
美国允许其制造业在海外进行的意愿招致了批评。咨询公司DBDC集团的分析师埃米莉•赫什(Emily Hersh)说：“我想说的是，在大型化石燃料公司面前，美国已经放弃了在能源方面进行技术创新。”赫什同时也是内华达州一家从事锂盐勘探项目的公司的首席执行官。 赫什说：“我们把一切都外包出去，以获得稍低的成本。我们已经把我们所使用和喜爱的技术背后的供应链，放到了成本更低的地区，或者没有严格环境政策的地区，这样我们就可以更便宜、更快地获得它们。” 2018年，时任美国总统唐纳德·特朗普(Donald Trump)发布了一项行政命令，旨在打破美国对海外矿产，尤其是中国矿产的依赖，宣布进入“国家紧急状态”，这在理论上将为国内采矿和加工开放资金。 新冠疫情造成的供应短缺促使华盛顿更加关注其关键进口的安全。拜登于2021年初入主白宫后，下令对被视为对国家安全至关重要的一系列进口产品的关键供应链进行进一步审查，包括矿产、药品和计算机芯片。
乔·拜登的基础设施法案提供了数十亿美元，以帮助促进美国对电池所需矿物质的加工
那年夏天晚些时候，美国能源部发布了一份蓝图，专门旨在恢复美国的电池供应链，包括通过鼓励“安全、公平和可持续”的国内采矿，确保生产电池所需的原材料的获取。并投资于回收废电池的过程，以重新利用电池中所含的矿物质。 美国能源部指出，中国主导着锂电池制造的供应链，包括矿石的加工。拜登的基础设施法案提供了数十亿美元，以帮助促进美国对电池所需矿物质的加工。 虽然目前美国只有一个锂矿在运营，但许多公司都在敦促采矿项目投入运营。Lithium Americas正计划在内华达州北部的Thacker Pass建造一座矿场，而总部位于澳大利亚的Ioneer USA Corp也希望在洛杉矶以北530公里处的内华达州南部建造一座大型矿场。其他几家公司正在提出从地热卤水中提取锂的项目，其中包括位于加州最大湖泊索尔顿海(Salton Sea)的一个项目。
在华盛顿，民主党和共和党的立法者都表示，他们将支持更新1872年的联邦法律，该法律对美国公共土地上的采矿进行管理。立法者们希望提高美国的采矿能力，并加入更有力的环境保护措施。虽然该法律不适用于加斯顿县的矿山，因为它被指定用于私人拥有的土地，但它将影响内华达州的绝大多数潜在矿山。 对硬岩开采的明确支持招致了环保人士的批评，他们认为政府应该把精力集中在回收活动上。 环境倡导组织Earthworks政策主管劳伦•佩格尔(Lauren Pagel)表示，美国必须“认真对待负责任的清洁能源矿产采购问题”。
澳大利亚格林布希(Greenbushes)的塔利森(Talison)锂矿的露天矿场
Earthworks组织表示，应该通过更好的回收举措来解决日益增长的矿物需求，并应更新该国的采矿法，以确保其保护环境和周围的流域。佩格尔说：“清洁能源转型不能建立在肮脏的采矿上。” 白宫官员曾表示，启动《国内生产法案》(Domestic Production Act)不会让矿业公司绕过或加快任何审批或环境审查程序。

挖洞

在北卡罗来纳州，皮埃蒙特锂业仍在努力通过第一阶段。该公司于2016年开始为其拟议的矿山购买土地，并进行了一些初步钻探，以确定潜在锂的存在和质量。 该公司表示，截至2020年6月中旬，它在该地区拥有或签订了约2126英亩的财产和相关矿权协议。那年9月，皮埃蒙特宣布与特斯拉达成了一项为期五年的协议，将向特斯拉供应锂辉石精矿，这种材料将从矿山中提取并加工成锂。同年晚些时候，该公司宣布将把公司从澳大利亚重新注册到美国。
皮埃蒙特在提交给美国证券交易委员会的文件中表示，根据该协议，特斯拉每年将收到约5.3万吨这种材料，为期5年，首批交付将于2022年7月至2023年7月之间。 但皮埃蒙特尚未获得开矿许可。在私人土地上开采硬岩的许可程序包括获得许可和通过州监管机构的环境检查，以及获得加斯顿县当地的土地使用许可。 该公司雄心勃勃的提议让加斯顿县的地方官员忙于更新他们几十年前的采矿规定，这些规定没有设想到皮埃蒙特想建造的那种类型和规模的矿场。在审查和更新他们的规则时，他们暂停了新的采矿。 加斯顿县专员查德·布朗(Chad Brown)将是考虑皮埃蒙特许可证申请的人之一，他说：“我们基本上需要把我们的房子整理好。”他还表示，他们收紧了规定，比如，禁止采矿在不适宜的时间进行。
皮埃蒙特锂矿计划的反对者在北卡罗莱纳州加斯顿县的路边放置了一个标志
2021年8月，皮埃蒙特锂业表示，它将不得不推迟从拟议中的矿山向特斯拉发运的第一批货物。在给英国《金融时报》的一份声明中，该公司表示，它将继续与州矿业官员努力工作，以最终敲定其州采矿许可证，并在准备申请加斯顿县监管的采矿许可时，定期向该县官员提供最新情况。 但在矿区附近生活和工作的人说，该公司并没有就他们的担忧与他们进行沟通。布莱恩·哈珀说，尽管该矿会破坏他的生意，但皮埃蒙特锂业没有直接与他联系。他说，他已经在多个公开会议上向他们提出了自己的担忧。 皮埃蒙特表示，它已“注意到哈珀的担忧”，并与工程师讨论了关于该项目是否会对其业务产生任何影响的最佳研究方案。
沃伦·斯诺登(Warren snowden)和他的妻子索尼娅(Sonya)看着他们家族财产附近的土地，这是北卡罗来纳州加斯顿县皮埃蒙特锂矿计划开发的一部分
该公司表示：“我们致力于成为一个好邻居，一个环境的好管家，一个好雇主，我们将接触哈珀先生——以及我们所有的邻居——在我们前进的过程中进行进一步的对话。” 就在距离布莱恩·哈珀几分钟车程的地方，埃里克·卡彭特(Eric Carpenter)一家拥有大约五英亩的土地，包括他85岁母亲的家。“我的家人对卖给皮埃蒙特不感兴趣，”卡彭特说。“他们告诉我们：‘卖掉，否则我们就在你周围开采’。" 皮埃蒙特表示，这一评论“没有反映我们的使命或价值观”。 卡彭特一家和其他人一样，将水源的潜在污染列为最关注的问题。埃里克·卡彭特已致信当地政客，要求暂停大型采矿项目，直到1971年管理北卡罗来纳州矿业的州法律得到更新，但未能获得任何暂停。
内华达州银峰附近的一个矿场，从盐水中提取锂
生物学家丽莎·斯特鲁普(Lisa Stroup)曾在另一家矿业公司FMC Lithium工作，她在回应皮埃蒙特锂业公司的许可证申请和实验室测试时，给北卡罗莱纳州当局写了几页详细的说明，表达对样本量和潜在的有毒采矿废物的担忧。 斯特鲁普说：“我最大的挫折之一，让我非常害怕的是，国家没有认真考虑这个问题。我们所在的社区已经负担过重。人们对我说，如果他们必须使用市政用水，我负担不起，所以我只能喝这些水。” 皮埃蒙特公司表示，其实验室测试和其他研究是“严格的许可程序”的一部分，由经验丰富、备受尊敬的科学家、水文地质学家、工程师和其他专家根据最佳实践和州和联邦当局制定的标准进行。
中国在制造锂电池的供应链中占主导地位，包括矿物的加工
布朗和其他掌握皮埃蒙特锂矿当地许可证命运的县委员会成员，迄今一直对该公司的做法持怀疑态度。 但布朗表示，他希望“尽可能走中间路线”。他表示：“我希望对他们进行尽职调查，听听他们的意见，同时回答反对者的问题。” 布朗说：“如果只是为了赚钱，(开矿)是最棒的，因为它带来了就业机会、金钱和那些耀眼夺目的商品。但不仅如此，它还与环境有关，与周围人的生活质量有关。”
interactive.eheadline: Powering electric cars: the race to mine lithium in America’s backyard
interactive.elongleadbody: The experience of one mining company in rural North Carolina suggests the road ahead will be hard to navigate
interactive.ebody:
At his small red brick farmhouse home near the Catawba river in the rural Piedmont region of North Carolina, Brian Harper is caught up in the dilemma facing America’s big push towards a future powered by green energy. Running in a band beneath the soil close to Harper’s land lies America’s biggest deposit of spodumene ore, a mineral that when processed into lithium is crucial to building rechargeable batteries of the kind used in electric vehicles. Seeing the business opportunity in this fast-growing area, Piedmont Lithium, a mining company originally incorporated in Australia, began knocking on the doors of the old houses surrounding a roughly 3,000-acre site several years ago, offering to buy up land so that it could start drilling a large pit mine to extract the mineral. With the International Energy Agency projecting a boom in demand that vastly exceeds planned supply in coming years, Piedmont found no difficulty pledging future sales of lithium to Tesla, America’s poster-child electric car company, even before they secured all of the necessary mining permits. But while it has successfully bought up some parcels of land, Piedmont Lithium has run into staunch opposition from many of its potential new neighbours, including Harper, who runs a small business making cogs and gears for industrial machinery just a little down the road from the proposed new mine.
Piedmont Lithium’s offices in Belmont, Gaston County. The company has run into staunch opposition from many of its potential new neighbours near its proposed mine
“When they start blasting and the floor is shaking, there’s no way my machinery will be able to function properly,” says Harper. In keeping with almost every home on the rural country roads running around and through the proposed mine site, Harper has a small picket sign in his front garden displaying a red stop sign and in large font, struck through with a red line: “Gaston County Pit Mine”. Others spoken to by the Financial Times argue that a hard rock mine of the size that Piedmont proposes would cause light, noise and dust pollution, as well as contaminate their water supply with poisonous runoff materials. Many of the houses surrounding the site of the proposed mine are not connected to a municipal water system, and instead extract their drinking water from wells, compounding worries that any accidental runoff or contamination of groundwater from the mine would poison their water sources. Piedmont Lithium says the company has “several” noise and dust mitigation plans in place, including limiting the number of trucks being used. It pledged to keep hazardous water out of surface water creeks, streams and the groundwater, and to monitor water quantity and quality in local wells. “If we become aware of any issue with local wells, it will be corrected,” the company says. Piedmont has argued in public meetings that its new mine, which would be accompanied by a processing plant, would bring new jobs to the area. But the company’s plan to launch one of the first big new lithium mines in decades, and only the second operational lithium mine in the US at present, has already fallen behind schedule. Construction was meant to be under way by 2020. As of May 2022, it has yet to apply for all of the permits it needs to break ground. The US electric vehicle battery industry is central to President Joe Biden’s plans to create a greener, more innovative economy, and his administration is determined to expand domestic mining of the minerals on which green technologies rely. At the end of March, it invoked the Korean-war era Defense Production Act to free up more money to be used to assist in the domestic mining of lithium, cobalt, nickel, graphite and manganese.
Macie Putnam and her mother, Cathi, inspect a map during a Piedmont Lithium public hearing held in November 2021 at the Gaston County Courthouse
But lithium represents perhaps the greatest opportunity for the US. The International Energy Agency named lithium as the mineral for which there was the fastest growing demand as the world transitions from oil and gas to a green energy grid. If the world is to meet the global climate targets set as part of the Paris Agreement, at least 40 times as much lithium will be needed by 2040 compared with today. The US holds about 8mn tonnes of lithium, according to the US Geological Survey, putting it in the top five most lithium-rich countries in the world. Yet it mines and processes only 1 per cent of global output. Much of the rest comes from China, Chile and Australia. As the US attempts to surge ahead in the global race to build batteries that will power the green transition, Washington is encouraging companies such as Piedmont to break ground on more mining projects across the continental United States. But it also wants to ensure state regulators, environmental activists and local communities are not left behind in the rush.

America in the race

The explosion in the electric vehicle market has set off a “battery arms race”, according to Simon Moores, chief executive of consultancy Benchmark Mineral Intelligence, which specialises in data on lithium ion batteries. Battery manufacturers will be trying to source the raw minerals needed to make batteries, including cobalt, nickel, graphite and lithium. Yet while scientists are having early success developing batteries that do not need cobalt or nickel to function, there are so far no leads on eliminating lithium. According to Moores, “lithium is the one that terrifies the industry”. The IEA says more than 80 per cent of the world’s lithium is mined in Australia, Chile and China, which alone controls more than half of the world’s processing and refining. The US has a single open lithium mine, in Nevada, and imports the majority of its supply from Argentina and Chile.
The US’s willingness to allow its manufacturing to take place overseas has attracted criticism. “America has, I would say, at the altar of the big fossil fuel companies, given up being technologically innovative when it comes to energy,” says Emily Hersh, an analyst at consultancy DBDC Group, and the chief executive of a company undertaking a lithium brine exploration project in Nevada. “We outsource everything for slightly lower costs,” says Hersh. “We have punted the supply chains behind the technology we use and love to cheaper jurisdictions, or jurisdictions without stringent environmental policy, so that we can get them cheaper and faster.” In 2018, then-president Donald Trump issued an executive order aimed at breaking the US dependence on minerals from abroad, especially from China, declaring a “national emergency” that would theoretically open up funding for domestic mining and processing. The supply shortages of the Covid-19 pandemic prompted Washington to pay even closer attention to the security of its critical imports. After Biden took over the White House, in early 2021, he ordered a further review of critical supply chains for a whole host of imports deemed important to national security, including minerals, pharmaceuticals and computer chips.
Joe Biden’s infrastructure bill has made billions of dollars available to help boost American processing of minerals needed for batteries
Later that summer, the US Department of Energy released a blueprint specifically aimed at reviving the US’s battery supply chain, including securing access to the raw minerals needed to make batteries by incentivising “safe, equitable and sustainable” domestic mining, and investing in processes to recycle dead batteries to re-use the minerals they hold. The DoE noted that China dominates the supply chain for the manufacturing of lithium batteries, including the processing of minerals. Biden’s infrastructure bill has made billions of dollars available to help boost American processing of minerals needed for batteries. While there is only one operational lithium mine in the US at present, a number of companies are pressing to get mining projects operational. Lithium Americas is planning a mine at Thacker Pass in Northern Nevada, while Australia-based Ioneer USA Corp also wants to build a large mine in southern Nevada, about 530km north of Los Angeles. Several other companies are proposing projects that would extract lithium from geothermal brine, including one at California’s largest lake in Salton Sea.
In Washington, both Democrats and Republican lawmakers have said they would support updating the federal law dated from 1872 that governs mining on American public lands. Lawmakers variously want to boost US mining capacity and insert more robust environmental protections. While that law does not apply to the Gaston County mine, which is being earmarked for privately owned land, it would affect the vast majority of potential mines in Nevada. The explicit support for hard rock mining has attracted criticism from environmentalists, who argue that the government should focus its efforts on recycling initiatives. Lauren Pagel, policy director at Earthworks, an environmental advocacy group, says the US must get “serious about responsible sourcing of clean energy minerals”.
An open pit mine at Talison Lithium’s site in Greenbushes, Australia
Earthworks has said the growing demand for minerals should be addressed by better recycling initiatives, and that it should update the country’s mining laws to make sure they protect the environment and surrounding watersheds. “The clean energy transition cannot be built on dirty mining,” she says. White House officials have said triggering the Domestic Production Act would not allow mining companies to bypass or expedite any permitting or environmental review processes.

Digging a hole

In North Carolina, Piedmont is still trying to get past stage one. The company first began acquiring land for its proposed mine in 2016, and has been carrying out some initial drilling to establish the presence and quality of the potential lithium.   By mid-June 2020, the company said it owned or had agreements on approximately 2,126 acres of property and associated mineral rights in the area. That September, Piedmont announced it had struck a five-year deal with Tesla and was set to supply the carmaker with spodumene concentrate, the material that would be extracted from the mine and processed into lithium. Late that year, it announced it would redomicile itself from Australia to the US.
In an SEC filing, Piedmont said the deal would see Tesla receive about 53,000 tonnes of the material a year for five years, with the first deliveries beginning between July 2022 and July 2023. But Piedmont has yet to obtain permits to begin mining. The permitting process for hard rock mining on private lands involves getting permission and passing environmental checks made by state regulators, as well as obtaining local county land-use permits in Gaston County. The company’s ambitious proposals have sent local officials in Gaston County scrambling to update their decades-old mining regulations, which did not envision a mine of the type and size that Piedmont wants to build. As they reviewed and updated their rules, they put a moratorium on new mining. “We basically needed to get our house in order,” says Chad Brown, a Gaston County commissioner who will be one of those considering a permit application from Piedmont, who said regulations were tightened to make sure that the mining did not occur at unsociable hours, for example.
A sign planted by opponents of Piedmont Lithium’s planned mine on a roadside in Gaston County, North Carolina
In August 2021, Piedmont said it would have to delay its first shipments from its proposed mine to Tesla. In a statement to the FT, the company says it is continuing to work diligently with state mining officials towards the finalisation of its state mining permit, and providing regular updates to Gaston County commissioners as it prepares to apply for the mining permissions that the county oversees. But people who live and work near the mine say the company has not been as communicative with them about their concerns. Brian Harper says that although the mine would destroy his business, he has not been directly contacted by Piedmont Lithium. He has raised his concerns with them in multiple public meetings, he says. Piedmont says it had “noted Mr Harper’s concern” and “discussed . . . the best course of study about whether the project will have any impact on his business” with its engineers.
Warren Snowdon and his wife Sonya view land abutting their family’s property, which is part of the planned development of Piedmont Lithium’s mine in Gaston County, North Carolina
“We are committed to being a good neighbour, a good steward of the environment and a good employer, and we will reach out to Mr Harper — and all our neighbours — to have further conversations as we move forward,” the company says.   Just a few minutes’ drive down the road from Brian Harper, Eric Carpenter’s family owns about five acres of land, including the home of his 85-year-old mother. “My family is not interested in selling to Piedmont,” says Carpenter. “They’re telling us: ‘sell, or we’ll mine around you’.” Piedmont says this comment did not “reflect our mission or values”. The Carpenter family, along with others, name the potential pollution of their water sources as a top concern. Eric Carpenter has written to his local politicians to request a moratorium on large mining projects until the 1971 state law governing mining in North Carolina can be updated, but was not able to secure any moratorium.
A mine near Silver Peak, Nevada, which extracts lithium from brine
Lisa Stroup, a biologist who has worked for another minerals company, FMC Lithium, has written pages of detailed notes to North Carolina state authorities in response to Piedmont Lithium’s permit application and lab testing to express concerns about the sample sizes and potential for toxic mining waste. “One of the big frustrations I have, one that makes me very fearful, is that the state is not giving this careful consideration,” says Stroup. “We are in a community that is already overburdened. People have said to me that if they’re made to tap into municipal water — I can’t afford it so I’m gonna have to just drink the water.” Piedmont says its lab testing and other studies are part of a “rigorous permitting process” and are being conducted by experienced and well-regarded scientists, hydrogeologists, engineers, and other experts in accordance with best practices and the standards set by the state and federal authorities.
China dominates the supply chain for the manufacturing of lithium batteries, including the processing of minerals
Brown and other county commissioners who hold the fate of Piedmont Lithium’s local permits in their hands have been sceptical about the company’s approach so far. But Brown says that he hopes to be “as middle of the road as I can”. “I want to give them due diligence and hear what they say, and also answer the questions of the naysayers,” he says. “If it’s just about money, [the mine] is the greatest thing, because it brings jobs and brings money and brings glorious things,” Brown says. “But it’s not just that, it has to do with the environment, the quality of life for the people who are surrounding it.”

interactive.cheadline: 迪士尼强劲流媒体订户增长令Netflix逊色
interactive.clongleadbody: 迪士尼最近一个季度新增790万新订户，远超预测。Netflix警告本季度将失去200万订户，导致股价大跌。
interactive.cbody:
华特迪士尼公司(Walt Disney)报告称，其流媒体服务Disney Plus在最近一个季度实现了强劲增长，这与行业领头羊Netflix最近订户数量下降形成了鲜明对比。

迪士尼增加了790万新订户，远高于预测的500万左右。就在几周前，Netflix警告本季度将失去200万订户，导致其股价大幅下跌，并引发了外界对全球视频流媒体市场潜在规模的担忧。

该公司的主题公园部门也出现了强劲反弹，季度收入同比增长逾一倍，至66亿美元，超出了华尔街的预期。

在此期间，Disney Plus的订户达到了1.377亿，而该公司的流媒体订户总数——包括Disney Plus、ESPN Plus和Hulu——达到了2.05亿。该集团首席执行官鲍勃·查派克(Bob Chapek)表示，Disney Plus有望在2024年前实现订户达到2.3亿至2.6亿的目标。

但迪士尼首席财务官克里斯汀·麦卡锡(Christine McCarthy)缓和了对今年下半年流媒体增长的预期。她说：“上半年的情况好于预期。但我们仍预计下半年的增幅将超过上半年。”

该公司股价在盘后交易中下跌3%。过去一年，迪士尼股价下跌逾40%，表现逊于标普500指数，后者过去一年下跌了约5.2%。

迪士尼报告季度营收192亿美元，较上年同期的156亿美元增长23%，但低于预期，因为该公司必须为提前终止电视节目和电影的版权支付10亿美元。该公司还对其在俄罗斯的资产进行了1.95亿美元的减值拨备。

迪士尼1.08美元的每股收益低于华尔街1.19美元的预期，原因是海外收益的实际税率上调。来自持续经营业务的净利润同比下降48%，从9.12亿美元降至4.7亿美元。

分析人士预计，在美国的带领下，迪士尼在疫情期间受到严重打击的主题公园今年将实现强劲复苏。主题公园部门当季营业收入达到37亿美元，同比增长50%。

在疫情期间，该公司用Disney Genie取代了FastPass服务，让顾客可以通过付费跳过排队。查派克表示，这些改善帮助美国主题公园的人均支出比2019年大流行前的水平增加了40%以上。“我们国内的主题公园表现非常出色。”他说。

但该公司警告称，包括香港和上海在内的亚洲主题公园的关闭，可能导致第三季度营业收入减少高达3.5亿美元。

在流媒体业务中，由于竞争导致内容预算飙升，投资者越来越关注成本。

查派克表示，迪士尼正在“密切关注内容成本的增长”。但他补充称，“优秀的内容将推动我们的订阅量，而订阅量将推动我们的盈利能力。”该公司表示，今年将削减整体电影和电视支出10亿美元，至320亿美元。

迪士尼的票房前景很好，皮克斯(Pixar)的《玩具总动员》(Toy Story)系列的最新作品《光年》(Lightyear)，《黑豹》(Black Panther)续集以及有史以来票房最高的《阿凡达》(Avatar)的续集都准备在今年底上映。其最新漫威电影《奇异博士2：疯狂多元宇宙》5月6日上映后在美国收获了1.85亿美元票房。

查佩克说，该公司推出广告支持版本的Disney Plus的计划已经取得了很大进展。Netflix上月表示，正在研究推出一个由广告支持的服务，这是该公司联席首席执行官里德•哈斯廷斯(Reed Hastings)长期以来一直反对的举措。Netflix还没有公开表示何时准备推出这项服务。
interactive.eheadline: Walt Disney gains ground on Netflix with strong growth in streaming
interactive.elongleadbody: Addition of 8mn new video subscribers beats forecasts while theme parks division doubles revenues
interactive.ebody: Walt Disney reported strong growth at its Disney Plus streaming service in its latest quarter, drawing a sharp contrast with the recent subscriber declines experienced by industry leader Netflix. Disney added 7.9mn new subscribers, well above projections of about 5mn. That healthy increase comes just weeks after Netflix warned it would lose 2mn subscribers in the current quarter, sparking a sharp sell-off in its shares and raising concerns about the potential size of the global video streaming market. The company’s theme parks division also had a strong rebound, where quarterly revenue more than doubled year-on-year to $6.6bn, beating Wall Street projections. Disney Plus reached 137.7mn subscribers, while the company’s total number of streaming subscribers — including Disney Plus, ESPN Plus and Hulu — reached 205mn in the period. Bob Chapek, the group’s chief executive, said Disney Plus is on track to meet its target of 230mn-260mn subscribers by 2024. But Christine McCarthy, Disney’s chief financial officer, tempered expectations for streaming growth in the second half of the year. “The first half came in better than expected, so that delta that we had initially anticipated may not be as large,” she said. “But we still do expect an increase in the second half to exceed the first half.” The company’s shares were down 3 per cent in after-hours trading. Disney shares has fallen more than 40 per cent over the past year, underperforming the S&P 500 stock index, which has lost about 5.2 per cent over the past year. Disney reported revenue of $19.2bn in the quarter, up 23 per cent from $15.6bn a year earlier, but missing estimates because it had to pay $1bn for early termination of rights for TV shows and films. It also took a $195mn impairment charge on its Russia assets. Disney’s earnings per share of $1.08 fell short of Wall Street forecasts of $1.19 because of an increase in the effective tax rate on foreign earnings. Net income from continuing operations fell 48 per cent year-on-year, to $470mn from $912mn. Analysts expected its theme parks — which were badly hit during the pandemic — to mount a strong recovery this year, led by the US. Operating income at the theme parks unit reached $3.7bn in the quarter, up 50 per cent from a year earlier. During the pandemic, the company replaced its FastPass service with Disney Genie, which allows customers to skip the queue for a fee. Chapek said such improvements had helped per capita spending at US parks rise more than 40 per cent from the pre-pandemic levels seen in 2019. “Our domestic parks were a standout,” he said. But the company warned that closures at its Asia theme parks, including Hong Kong and Shanghai, could cut operating income by up to $350mn in the third quarter. In the streaming business, investors have grown more focused costs as competition has sent content budgets skyrocketing. Chapek said Disney is “carefully watching content cost growth”. But he added that “great content is going to drive our subscriptions, and those will drive our profitability”. The company said it will cut overall film and TV spending by $1bn to $32bn this year. Disney has a strong theatrical slate ahead, with Pixar’s Lightyear, the latest in its Toy Story franchise, and sequels to Black Panther and Avatar, the highest grossing film of all time, prepared for release at the end of the year. Its latest Marvel film, Dr. Strange in the Multiverse of Madness, grossed $185mn in the US after its release on May 6. Chapek said the company is far along in its plans to launch an advertising-supported version of Disney Plus. Netflix said last month it was exploring the launch of an advert-supported tier, a step that co-chief executive Reed Hastings had long opposed. Netflix has not publicly said when it will be ready to launch the service.

interactive.cheadline: 谁来为乌克兰的重建买单？
interactive.clongleadbody: 战后重建将取决于减少腐败和与欧盟建立真正的紧密关系 。
interactive.cbody:
波罗季扬卡(Borodyanka)音乐学校的校址已经被轰炸成几堆残垣断壁。在俄罗斯和乌克兰军队的战斗中被彻底摧毁，建筑的其余部分现在已经被彻底地夷为平地。 自俄罗斯军队3月底撤离该地区以来，市政工作人员在清理废墟方面做得非常出色。但波罗季扬卡(Borodyanka)遭受的破坏是无法掩饰的。这是基辅西北部受损最严重的城镇，在莫斯科2月24日开始入侵基辅后，在试图夺取首都的行动失败后，波罗季扬卡首当其冲。 这所音乐学校位于中央大街，入侵的俄罗斯坦克在这里遭遇了乌克兰军队的顽强抵抗。在同一条路上，邮局、市政行政大楼、区行政办公室、警察总部、文化中心和几座公寓楼都被摧毁。 在城对面作为临时办公室的教室里，副市长格奥尔基·叶尔科(Georgy Yerko)正在查阅他的名单。397座建筑，包括9座高层住宅区被毁，888座被损坏，17000平方米的窗户被震碎。当被问及是否可以为这些损失定价时，他摇了摇头，指出即使是没有被炸弹或子弹击中的房屋，管道也可能因缺乏热量而爆裂。但他知道谁应该承担这个代价：俄罗斯。 叶尔科说："破坏的一方才应该是赔偿的一方。"
波罗迪扬卡是基辅西北部受损最严重的城镇，2月24日入侵开始后，莫斯科试图占领首都的企图失败，波罗迪扬卡首当其冲
虽然令人震惊，但波罗季扬卡的损失，在战前有1.3万人口，只是俄罗斯入侵对该国造成的损失的一小部分。在俄罗斯的围攻下，东南部港口城市马里乌波尔(Mariupol)大部分被夷为平地，该城市的人口是俄罗斯的40倍。 即便破坏仍在继续，在战争中支持乌克兰的西方政府，也开始权衡战后重建工作所需的成本和规划。这场重建工作将与二战以来的任何重建工作媲美。 官员们警告说，这项工程将非常复杂，耗资巨大，将耗资数千亿欧元，而且它必须远远超出仅仅重建桥梁和市政建筑的范围。这将导致乌克兰私营部门的大规模重建，并对该国经济进行改革。在经历了8年不断升温的冲突之后，今年乌克兰经济产出将暴跌45%。 战后重建的命运将取决于乌克兰的一些生存问题，战争使这些问题变得更加紧迫：乌克兰是否能从困扰它的腐败和寡头横行的体系中解脱出来，以及它是否能与欧盟建立真正的密切关系，甚至包括加入欧盟。这也将取决于俄罗斯是否会为任何损害付出代价。 鉴于俄罗斯对乌克兰的攻击还没有结束的迹象，欧盟官员对于他们能够、甚至应该在多大程度上计划这场令人担忧的重建演习存在分歧。但他们很清楚，如果最终进程处理不当，对乌克兰和整个欧洲的安全都将是灾难性的。
副市长奥尔基·叶尔科(中)和同事们在城市另一端的一个教室里，这是他的临时办公室
“国际社会和私营部门都非常愿意投资于乌克兰的重建，但这种热情能持续多久，将取决于资金的有效使用。”欧洲复兴开发银行(European Bank for Reconstruction and Development)首席经济学家贝娅塔•贾沃西克(Beata Javorcik)警告称。该银行将是密切参与这项工作的机构之一。 “最具挑战性的方面是重建体制框架。在战前，乌克兰在商业环境或高质量的机构方面并不是一个典范。” 在本月早些时候的一次讲话中，欧盟委员会主席乌苏拉·冯·德莱恩(Ursula von der Leyen)表示，欧盟对乌克兰的复兴项目的目标将包括打击腐败，使乌克兰符合欧洲法律标准。 她对欧洲议会表示：“这将带来稳定和确定性，使乌克兰成为吸引外国直接投资的目的地。最终，它将为乌克兰在欧盟的未来铺平道路。”

重建工作

从某种程度上说，鉴于乌克兰大部分地区正在进行的战斗，谈论重建乌克兰似乎为时过早。事实上，乌克兰合作伙伴的首要任务是保持武器供应、人道主义援助和填补估计每月50亿美元的资金缺口所需的流动资金。 华盛顿全球发展中心(Center for Global Development)高级研究员斯科特•莫里斯(Scott Morris)表示，只有在“事实上或法律上的稳定”的环境下，才有可能持久地重建该国的经济和基础设施。 但这并没有阻止乌克兰政府开始在该国已结束战斗的地区进行重建。在恢复重要服务、重建住房和挽救乌克兰经济的生产能力方面存在着一场持续的竞赛。
乌克兰的经济学家们也开始计算俄罗斯入侵造成的不断增长的支出，他们正在为短期和长期援助寻找理由。 乌克兰基辅经济学院的纳塔利亚·沙波瓦尔(Nataliia Shapoval)和其他经济学家在入侵的第二天开始对乌克兰的损失进行分类。他们从一个自我报告的网站开始，很快就建立了一个乌克兰基础设施受损情况的数据库，并与政府合作，将其数据和其他官方来源纳入其中。 KSE对基础设施直接损失的最新估计达到920亿美元。根据他们对总损失(包括增长、投资和经济潜力)的“粗略”计算，总损失在5000亿至6000亿美元之间。 沙波瓦尔说，重要的是现在就开始重建，以保障乌克兰部分经济的正常运行，否则捐助国的长期财政负担将会更大。 乌克兰及其盟友开始规划重建工作的理由得到了该国总统本人的赞同。 沃迪米尔·泽连斯基(Volodymyr Zelensky)上周在华沙的一个捐助者会议上发表演讲，概述了他的重建方法。他表示，资金规模需要很大，这是“现代版的马歇尔计划”，包括“技术、专家和增长机会”。他还呼吁个别国家充当乌克兰个别城市或地区的赞助人，帮助他们重建。 泽连斯基补充说，重建工作应该与获得欧盟成员国资格的快速通道同时进行：“现在就授予候选资格——在战争条件下。这是欧盟成员国特殊简化程序的一部分。”
上周，公共工人在波罗季扬卡进行电力维修。乌克兰正在进行一场恢复重要服务、重建住房和恢复经济生产能力的竞赛
后者涉及到这一进程中政治上最敏感的一个方面。 在欧盟内部，乌克兰的成员资格问题引起了巨大的争议。许多成员国认为，鉴于乌克兰饱受战争摧残，很快就能加入欧盟的想法不仅不靠谱，而且还能造成分裂，因为这还向坐在等待室里的欧盟长期候选国传递了不一样的意味。 但布鲁塞尔也很清楚，不管是否加入欧盟，鉴于乌克兰就在家门口，最终将是欧洲承担重建努力的最大份额成本。布鲁塞尔和其他地方的官员认为，将重建工作与获得欧盟候选国资格的国家往往需要进行的密集改革和监督结合起来是有利的。 他们希望，最终加入欧盟的承诺将吸引外国投资者，同时也能让乌克兰公众参与到痛苦的改革过程中来，提高战后乌克兰成功重建的机会。 世界银行(World Bank)乌克兰国家局局长奥雅纳•贝纳吉(Arup Banerji)表示，鉴于欧盟有能力充当乌克兰的“锚和模式”，乌克兰着眼于“最终候选国家乃至更大程度上的最终入盟”，这一事实使其处于比其他战后国家更有利的地位。
这些改革的核心内容之一将是解决地方性腐败问题——确保捐助者和贷款人的资金不被窃取，并为国家的长期发展建立一个更稳定的基础。 财政部长谢尔盖•马尔琴科(sergei Marchenko)表示，当务之急是修复桥梁和窗户，恢复受影响城市的水电供应。但他表示，现在也是时候反思国家的经济选择，以及支撑这些选择所需的体制改革，特别是反腐败保障措施和加强法治。 “现在这不仅仅是钱的问题。这是一个原则问题。乌克兰应该如何吸引外国直接投资？”他说。 然而，加州大学伯克利分校(Berkeley)经济学教授尤里•戈罗德尼琴科(Yuriy Gorodnichenko)警告称，问题在于，乌克兰过去未能兑现承诺，以换取国际金融支持。 欧洲审计院(European Court of Auditors) 9月份的一份报告发现，尽管欧盟不断努力改善乌克兰的法治，“严重的腐败和国家控制在乌克兰是地方性的：它们不仅阻碍竞争和增长，也损害民主进程。” “我希望这次会有所不同，”乌克兰人戈罗德尼琴科补充道。“但现实是，我们的机构相当薄弱。这就是为什么我们需要一个外部支持”，比如加入欧盟的可能性。

新的马歇尔计划

对于未来重建乌克兰的努力，布鲁塞尔最喜欢的比喻是第二次世界大战后的马歇尔计划——鉴于该重建努力的积极含义，这也许是不可避免的。但官员们很清楚，还有其他不那么令人鼓舞的先例，强调了该项目出现问题的风险。 2003年至2014年，在以美国为首的入侵伊拉克并推翻萨达姆•侯赛因(Saddam Hussein)政权之后，伊拉克用于重建的资金约为2200亿美元。世界银行的数据显示，捐款最多的是伊拉克政府，其次是美国，支出了600亿美元。 然而，世行2019年发布的一份报告发现，根据对政府机构的采访，“考虑到投入的资源，重建的影响仍然令人失望地模糊”，而且普遍存在腐败现象。
上个月，乌苏拉·冯·德莱恩和乌克兰总统弗拉基米尔·泽连斯基在基辅握手，欧盟外交事务和安全政策高级代表约瑟夫·博雷尔在一旁观看
世界银行的贝纳吉说，有几个理由让我们对乌克兰战后的前景比伊拉克的前景更乐观。他说，关键的一点是，尽管战时状况仍在持续，但该国仍有一个“运转良好的政府”，以及一个运转良好的金融体系。它还有一个政府，用他的话来说，决心带头并“掌控”最终的重建进程。 乌克兰政界人士一再强调，重建工作不能听命于国外。乌克兰国会议员、经济发展委员会主席德米特罗·库勒巴(Dmytro Natalukha)说，这种模式不应该是赞助，而应该是“适当的伙伴关系”。 “我们不想成为金融和资本的黑洞，”他说。“我们不是一个想成为世界乞丐的国家。”

俄罗斯能否偿还损失？

在关于重建乌克兰的最佳战略的辩论中，悬而未决的是一个更基本的问题：钱到底从哪里来。 官员们表示，世界银行、国际货币基金组织(IMF)和欧洲复兴开发银行(EBRD)等多边贷款机构将深入参与任何重建乌克兰的努力，这是合乎情理的。但考虑到它们在世界各地面临的竞争需求，它们的资源只能发挥到目前为止。 美国在承诺提供的支持规模方面表现突出，乔•拜登(Joe Biden)上月请求国会批准向乌克兰提供85亿美元的经济援助，作为330亿美元援助计划的一部分。这是前一个月批准的140亿美元。 但布鲁塞尔的官员们已经在讨论筹集资金的方式，这些资金将超过上述金额。正在讨论的想法包括发行新一轮欧盟共同债务，以推动重建，可能模仿疫情后旨在重建欧盟的筹资努力。冯·德莱恩告诉欧洲议会，需要一个“雄心勃勃的复苏计划”来带来大规模投资和改革。
“波罗季扬卡很好。但它会更好，”25岁的居民纳迪亚(Nadia)说
她表示，这将包括一个里程碑和目标体系，以确保资金能够交付，这与为帮助疫情恢复而设立的8000亿欧元“下一代欧盟”(NextGenerationEU)借款计划中使用的方法相呼应。 与此相关的问题是，作为最终经济改革的一部分，乌克兰是否需要重组自己的外债。马尔琴科坚持说，继续偿还债务是重中之重，因为政府希望继续进入当地和国际资本市场。但许多分析人士认为，乌克兰债务重组更多的是一个何时进行的问题，而不是是否进行重组的问题。 欧盟及其盟国也在积极考虑，如果俄罗斯能做出贡献，如何弥补其军队造成的一些损害。欧盟和美国意识到，任何战争赔偿的概念似乎都是遥不可及的，因此它们想方设法没收俄罗斯资产，以帮助支付赔偿费用。 例如，华盛顿和布鲁塞尔正在研究如何没收和出售受到制裁的俄罗斯寡头的资产——尽管法律障碍是巨大的，而且任何收益最终都将与重建工作相形见绌。 另一个选择是寻找俄罗斯中央银行的外汇储备，这些储备在入侵后不久被冻结。这些储备提供了一个更有利可图的目标，因为它们高达数千亿欧元。
波罗季扬卡被毁坏的房屋。乌克兰经济学家已经开始计算俄罗斯入侵造成的不断增长的账单
欧盟最高外交官博雷尔(Josep Borrell)就是主张采取这一行动的人之一。博雷尔对英国《金融时报》表示：“我非常赞成，因为它充满了逻辑。这是摆在桌面上最重要的政治问题之一：谁来为乌克兰的重建买单？” 尽管有没收主权资产的先例(包括美国今年早些时候对阿富汗央行采取的行动)，但考虑到涉及的金额，控制俄罗斯外汇储备将标志着一种新的、具有煽动性的做法。 对一些欧盟官员来说，在战争肆虐之际就重建资金展开辩论，可能会分散人们对更紧迫的战争优先事项的注意力。但其他人认为，这场辩论至关重要，必须现在就开始——尤其是因为讨论乌克兰最终可以重建成什么样子，给一个饱受死亡、破坏和恐惧折磨的国家带来了希望。 戈罗德尼琴科(Gorodnichenko)说：“在隧道的尽头看到光明，显然极大地鼓舞了乌克兰人的士气，尤其是被占领领土上的人。有一种未来会更好的感觉，会让我们更容易度过这些黑暗的日子。” 纳迪娅与她的孩子们在波罗季扬卡的秋千上玩耍，她指着被俄罗斯炸弹炸毁一半的烧焦的公寓楼。"她说：“我们需要重建，以摆脱这种情况。”波罗季扬卡很好。但它将会更好。"

interactive.elongleadbody: Postwar reconstruction will hinge on reducing corruption and forging a genuinely close relationship with the EU
interactive.ebody:
The remains of Borodyanka’s music school have been cleared into several piles of twisted metal. Completely destroyed in fighting between Russian and Ukrainian forces, the rest of what is left of the building is now neatly raked dust. Municipal workers have done a remarkable job of cleaning up the debris since Russian forces withdrew from the area at the end of March. But there is no hiding the devastation in Borodyanka, the most badly damaged of the towns north-west of Kyiv, which bore the brunt of Moscow’s failed attempt to take the capital after the invasion began on February 24. The music school is on Central Street, where advancing Russian tanks met ferocious resistance from Ukrainian forces. On the same road, the post office, municipal administration building, district administration office, police headquarters, a cultural centre and several apartment blocks have all been destroyed. In a classroom across town that serves as his makeshift office, Georgy Yerko, the deputy district mayor, consults his list: 397 buildings including nine high-rise residential blocks obliterated, 888 damaged, 17,000 square metres of windows shattered. Asked whether he can put a price on the losses, he shakes his head, pointing out that even in houses untouched by bombs or bullets, the pipes may have burst due to lack of heat. But he knows who should carry the cost: Russia. “The side that destroys should be the side that pays,” Yerko says.
Borodyanka, the most badly damaged of the towns north-west of Kyiv, bore the brunt of Moscow’s failed attempt to take the capital after the invasion began on February 24
Although shocking, the losses in Borodyanka, which before the war had a population of 13,000, are a tiny fraction of those inflicted on the country by Russia’s invasion. Mariupol, the south-eastern port city that has been mostly levelled in a Russian siege, had a population 40 times larger. Even as the destruction continues, the western governments that have backed Ukraine in the war are beginning to weigh up the costs and planning that will be needed for a postwar reconstruction effort that will rival anything seen since the second world war. The project, officials warn, is going to be immensely complex and costly, running into hundreds of billions of euros, and it will have to go far beyond simply rebuilding bridges and municipal buildings. It will entail the wholesale reconstruction of Ukraine’s private sector and reforms to an economy that, after suffering from eight years of simmering conflict, is in line for a 45 per cent crash in output this year. The fate of postwar reconstruction will hinge on some of the existential questions about Ukraine that the war has only made more urgent: whether its state can free itself from the corruption and oligarch-strewn system that has plagued it, and whether it can forge a genuinely close relationship with the EU that might even include membership. It will also depend on whether Russia will ever pay for any of the damage. EU officials are divided over how intensively they can or even should be planning for this fraught reconstruction exercise given there is no end in sight to Russia’s assault on the country. But they are clear that if the eventual process is mishandled, it would be disastrous both for Ukraine and for wider European security.
Deputy mayor Georgy Yerko, centre, with co-workers in a classroom across town that serves as his makeshift office
“There is enormous willingness among the international community and private actors to invest in the rebuilding of Ukraine, but how long this enthusiasm lasts will depend on the money being spent well,” warns Beata Javorcik, the chief economist of the European Bank for Reconstruction and Development, which will be one of the institutions closely involved in the effort. “The most challenging aspect is rebuilding the institutional framework: Ukraine was no model in terms of business environment or high-quality institutions prior to the war.” In a speech earlier this month, president of the European Commission Ursula von der Leyen said the goals of the EU’s recovery project for Ukraine would include the fight against corruption and aligning Ukraine with European legal standards. “This will bring the stability and certainty needed to make Ukraine an attractive destination for foreign direct investment,” she told the European parliament. “And eventually, it will pave the way for Ukraine’s future inside the European Union.”

The rebuilding effort

On one level, talk of rebuilding Ukraine might seem tragically premature given the ongoing fighting across large parts of the country. And indeed, the top priority for Ukraine’s partners is keeping it supplied with weapons, humanitarian aid and the liquidity needed to plug a financing gap estimated at $5bn a month. Any lasting effort to rebuild the country’s economy as well as infrastructure will only be possible in an environment of “de facto or de jure stability,” says Scott Morris, a senior fellow at the Center for Global Development in Washington. But this has not stopped the Ukrainian government from starting to rebuild in parts of the country where fighting has ended. There is a continual race to restore vital services, rebuild housing and salvage productive capacity in the Ukrainian economy.
Ukrainian economists have also started to calculate the ever-growing bill caused by Russia’s invasion, as they make the case for immediate and longer-term assistance. Nataliia Shapoval and fellow economists at the Kyiv School of Economics Institute began to catalogue the damage to Ukraine on the second day of the invasion. They started with a website for self-reporting and soon built a database of damage to Ukraine’s physical infrastructure, working with the government to include its data and other official sources. The KSE’s latest estimate of the direct damage to infrastructure reached $92bn. Their “back of the envelope” calculation of total losses, including growth, investment and economic potential, comes to between $500bn and $600bn. It is important to start reconstruction now, says Shapoval, in order to safeguard functioning parts of the Ukrainian economy, otherwise the longer-term financial burden on donor countries would be even bigger. The case for Ukraine and its allies to start planning the rebuilding effort is echoed by the country’s president himself. Volodymyr Zelensky outlined his approach to reconstruction in a speech to a donors’ conference in Warsaw last week. Funding needed to be massive in scale, he said, a “modern analogue to the Marshall plan” including “technology, specialists and growth opportunities”. He also called on individual countries to act as patrons for individual Ukrainian cities or regions, helping them to rebuild. Zelensky added that reconstruction should go hand in hand with a fast track to EU membership: “Candidate status granted right now — in conditions of war. As part of a special abridged procedure for EU membership.”
Communal workers carry out electrical repairs last week in Borodyanka. A race is under way to restore vital services, rebuild housing and salvage productive capacity in the Ukrainian economy
The latter point touches on one of the most politically sensitive aspects of the process. The topic of Ukrainian membership is hugely controversial within the EU, where many member states view the notion of Ukraine entering the union soon as being not only implausible, given that the country is ravaged by a war, but also divisive given the message it sends to longstanding EU candidates sitting in the waiting room. But Brussels is also well aware that, accession or not, it will be Europe that ends up bearing the lion’s share of the costs of the reconstruction effort given that Ukraine is on its doorstep. Officials in Brussels and elsewhere see advantages in twinning the reconstruction effort with the intensive reforms and monitoring that tend to be required of countries that gain the status of EU candidate. The promise of eventual EU membership would attract foreign investors, they hope, while also keeping the Ukrainian public engaged in the painful process of reform — enhancing the chances of a successful rebuilding of postwar Ukraine. Arup Banerji, the World Bank’s country director for Ukraine, says the fact that Ukraine has its sights on “eventual candidacy and even more eventual accession” puts it in a stronger position than other postwar societies, given the EU’s ability to serve as an “anchor and a model” for the country.
One of the central planks of those reforms will be to tackle endemic corruption — ensuring donors’ and lenders’ cash is not stolen and creating a more stable foundation for the country in the longer term. Sergii Marchenko, finance minister, says the immediate priority is to repair bridges and windows and to restore electricity and water supplies in affected cities. But he said it was also time to reflect on economic choices for the country and the kind of institutional reforms needed to underpin them, especially anti-corruption safeguards and bolstering the rule of law. “Now it is not just a question of money. It is a question of principles. What should Ukraine do to attract foreign direct investment?” he says. The problem, however, warns Yuriy Gorodnichenko, a professor of economics at Berkeley, is that Ukraine has in the past failed to deliver its promises in return for international financial support. A report by the European Court of Auditors as recently as September found that despite repeated efforts by the EU to improve the rule of law there, “grand corruption and state capture are endemic in Ukraine: as well as hindering competition and growth, they also harm the democratic process.” “I hope this time will be different,” adds Gorodnichenko, who is Ukrainian. “But the reality is our institutions are pretty weak. That is why we need an external anchor” such as the possibility of accession to the EU.

The new Marshall Plan

The favoured analogy in Brussels for future efforts to reconstruct Ukraine is the Marshall Plan following the second world war — perhaps inevitably given the positive connotations of that reconstruction effort. But officials are well aware that there are other, less encouraging precedents that underline the risks of the project going awry. Some $220bn was spent on the reconstruction of Iraq between 2003 and 2014 following the US-led invasion and overthrow of Saddam Hussein’s regime. The biggest contributions came from Iraq’s government followed by the US, which spent $60bn, according to the World Bank. Yet a 2019 report from the Bank found that, based on interviews with government agencies, “the impact of reconstruction remains disappointingly obscure considering the resources committed” and was undermined by widespread corruption.
Ursula von der Leyen and Ukraine president Volodymyr Zelensky shake hands, as EU High Representative for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy Josep Borrell looks on, in Kyiv last month
Banerji, of the World Bank, says there are several reasons to be more optimistic about Ukraine’s postwar prospects than those of Iraq. The key one is that the country still has a “well-functioning government” despite the ongoing wartime conditions, he says, as well as a functioning financial system. It also has a government that, in his words, is determined to take the lead and “own” the eventual reconstruction process. Ukrainian politicians repeatedly stress the importance of the rebuilding effort not being dictated from abroad. Dmytro Natalukha, a Ukrainian MP who heads the committee on economic development, says the model should not be sponsorship but “a proper partnership”. “We don’t want to be a black hole for finance and capital,” he says. “We are not a nation that wants to become a worldwide beggar.”

Can Russia repay the damage?

Hanging over the debate on the best strategy for rebuilding Ukraine is the more basic question of where exactly the money will come from. Officials say it stands to reason that multilateral lenders such as the World Bank, IMF and EBRD will be deeply involved in any efforts to rebuild Ukraine. But their resources will only go so far given the competing demands they face around the world. The US has stood out for the scale of the support being promised, with Joe Biden last month asking Congress to authorise $8.5bn of economic aid for Ukraine as part of a $33bn package for the country. This is on top of $14bn approved the month before. But officials in Brussels are already discussing ways of raising funds that would exceed those sums. The ideas being debated include a fresh round of common EU debt issuance to fuel the reconstruction, potentially modelled on fundraising efforts aimed at rebuilding the EU following Covid. Von der Leyen told the European Parliament that an “ambitious recovery package” would be needed to bring both massive investment and reforms.
‘Borodyanka was good. But it will be even better,’ says resident Nadia, 25
This would contain a system of milestones and targets to make sure the money delivers, she said, echoing the approach used in the €800bn NextGenerationEU borrowing programme, which was created to help recover from the pandemic. Allied to this is the question of whether Ukraine will need to restructure its own external debts as part of an eventual economic overhaul. Marchenko has insisted keeping up debt repayments is a priority because the government wanted to retain its access to local and international capital markets. But many analysts see Ukrainian debt restructuring as more a question of when, rather than if. The EU and its allies are also actively looking at how, if at all, Russia can be made to contribute to remedying some of the damage its army has caused. Conscious of how distant any notion of war reparations seems, the EU and the US have looked at ways of seizing Russian assets to help pay for the effort. Washington and Brussels are, for instance, looking at ways of confiscating and selling assets of Russian oligarchs who are subject to sanctions — although the legal hurdles are formidable and any proceeds would ultimately be dwarfed by the reconstruction effort. Another option is to look to foreign exchange reserves of the Russian central bank, which were frozen soon after the invasion. These provide a far more lucrative target, given they run into the hundreds of billions of euros.
Damaged houses in Borodyanka. Ukrainian economists have started to calculate the ever-growing bill caused by Russia’s invasion
Among those who have advocated this course of action is Josep Borrell, the EU’s top diplomat. “I would be very much in favour because it is full of logic,” Borrell told the FT. “This is one of the most important political questions on the table: who is going to pay for the reconstruction of Ukraine?” While there are precedents for seizures of sovereign assets, including US action against Afghanistan’s central bank early this year, taking control of Russian reserves would mark a new and incendiary departure given the sums at stake. To some EU officials, even starting the debate on reconstruction funding when the war is raging risks distracting from far more immediate wartime priorities. But others argue the debate is an essential one to begin now — not least because discussion of what Ukraine could ultimately be rebuilt into offers hope to a country blighted by death, destruction and fear. “Having light at the end of the tunnel is obviously a huge morale boost for Ukrainians, especially for people in the occupied territories,” Gorodnichenko says. “Having a sense the future will be better will make it easier to survive these dark days.” Playing with her children on the swings in Borodyanka, Nadia points to a charred apartment block that was half demolished by a Russian bomb. “We need reconstruction to get rid of this,” she says. “Borodyanka was good. But it will be even better.”

interactive.cheadline: KKR与黑石集团接洽联合收购东芝事宜
interactive.clongleadbody: 这两家私人股本集团准备联合竞购东芝，为与贝恩资本的对决创造条件。
interactive.cbody:
美国私募股权投资集团KKR已与黑石集团接触，准备联合竞购东芝，为与贝恩资本的对决创造条件。

据直接了解讨论情况的人士称，在东芝表示将成立一个特别委员会来评估私人股本和其他投资者的潜在出价后，这两个集团在最近几周进行了初步会谈。

他们补充说，收购预计将由KKR牵头，但谈判仍处于早期阶段，尚未达成正式决定。

在贝恩于4月获得东芝最大股东新加坡投资基金Effissimo对收购交易的合格支持后，KKR和黑石集团对此表示了兴趣。

KKR和黑石集团拒绝就谈判置评，彭博(Bloomberg)首先报道了谈判。

东芝的市值为180亿美元。对东芝进行私有化交易，将标志着私人股本进军亚洲最大发达经济体的一个分水岭。

不过，鉴于将这个拥有146年历史的品牌私有化面临重大政治障碍，目前仍不清楚私人股本集团计划如何构建这笔交易。该品牌的业务涵盖核能、国防和半导体等敏感领域。

银行家和律师们表示，日本当局不太可能批准由一家全外资财团全面收购东芝，并可能要求政府支持的投资基金或其它日本合作伙伴参与。

东芝高管历来抵制将该集团私有化，但该公司已被迫探索这一选择，以解决多年来的金融动荡以及与持有该日本集团大量股份的维权股东的冲突。

长期以来，许多大型私人股本集团一直将日本视为一个热门目标，因为日本拥有丰富的技术、工业和制造业专长。许多大公司，如贝恩资本，已经从该地区获得了一些最好的回报。

一些全球收购基金一直关注企业创始人的大规模资产出售，以及日本企业集团在股东要求其提高价值的压力下剥离出来的业务。

但是，即使是像贝恩和KKR这样经验丰富的投资者，要完成大型交易仍然是一项微妙的任务，需要多年的努力和建立关系。

一位私人股本高管最近表示：“未来在日本的去集团化和支持创始人主导的企业方面有很大机会。”他警告称：“这不是一个容易进入的市场。失败的人比成功的人多得多。”

interactive.cheadline: Coinbase首席执行官称公司“没有破产风险”
interactive.clongleadbody: 在公布惨淡的业绩和新的披露文件曝光后，这家加密货币交易所的股价下跌了23%。
interactive.cbody:
周三，在公布惨淡的业绩后，加密货币交易所Coinbase的股价下跌近四分之一，而该公司首席执行官立即出面平息他称之为的不必要的破产担忧。 Coinbase股价下跌23%，此前该公司于周二公布了第一季度业绩，营收大幅下滑，低于分析师预期，交易量也大幅下降。 糟糕的业绩加上对当日晚些时候提交的监管文件的担忧，促使首席执行官布莱恩•阿姆斯特朗(Brian Armstrong)在Twitter上表示，Coinbase“没有破产的风险”。 在他发表这番言论之前，一项新的披露文件显示，客户可能会对该交易所提出索赔，这在Coinbase的用户中间引发恐慌。 根据这份文件，Coinbase为用户保管的加密货币“可能会受到破产程序的影响，这些客户可能被视为我们的一般无担保债权人”。因此，用户可能会发现该平台“风险更大，吸引力更低”，可能会损害其财务健康。 但阿姆斯特朗立即安抚用户，为自己在添加新措辞时未能“主动”沟通而道歉。
阿姆斯特朗在推特上表示：“关于我们今天在10Q（监管文件）中对我们如何持有加密货币资产的披露，有一些噪音。”他补充说，该交易所并没有面临破产风险，只是更改了条款，以满足监管要求。 Wedbush的分析师指出，Coinbase“现金充裕”，在经济低迷时期仍在“积极”投资。 在其第一季度财报中，该公司报告了比华尔街预期更大的亏损——4.3亿美元，而分析师此前预估为4700万美元。该公司还预计本季度交易量和用户数量将继续下降。 自今年年初以来，Coinbase股价已下跌67%，导致自该公司去年4月上市以来股价首次跌破100美元。Coinbase首次公开发行时的股价为381美元。 Coinbase的业务健康状况长期以来一直在跟踪更广泛的加密货币市场的趋势，受益于去年上半年散户投资者的投机交易热潮。在2021年牛市期间，该公司的利润超过了更成熟的交易所运营商，包括芝加哥商品交易所集团(CME Group)和洲际交易所(Intercontinental Exchange)。 然而，最近的加息已让投资者逃离全球金融市场中风险最高的角落，造成了加密货币熊市，被称为最新的“加密货币寒冬”。 比特币最近大幅下跌，本周自去年7月早些时候以来首次跌破3万美元，原因是稳定币Terra价格狂泻导致加密货币市场出现大范围动荡。 Coinbase还面临监管障碍。周二，阿姆斯特朗在与分析师的电话会议上表示，由于来自印度储备银行的“非正式压力”，该公司在印度市场停止了仅推出几天的服务。阿姆斯特朗此前曾与美国监管机构发生过摩擦，后者目前正在围绕该行业展开调查。 去年，他指责美国证交会(SEC)“行为草率”，此前SEC威胁如果该公司推出一种特定的借贷产品，将起诉该公司。Coinbase后来搁置了Lend产品的计划。 尽管业绩不如人意，但阿姆斯特朗和其他高管一再向投资者保证，经济低迷对公司来说可能是一个机会，使其能够专注于业务多元化，投资于产品创新和招聘人才。该公司最近推出了一个非同质代币市场，并一直在探索加密衍生品等领域。 Coinbase在致股东信的结尾签署了#wagmi，这是一个在加密社区很流行的标签，意思是“我们都会成功”(we are all gonna make it)。
interactive.eheadline: Coinbase chief says ‘no risk of bankruptcy’ after regulatory filing sparks alarm
interactive.elongleadbody: Shares in cryptocurrency exchange fall 23% after bleak results and new risk disclosure
interactive.ebody:
Shares in cryptocurrency exchange Coinbase lost almost a quarter of their value on Wednesday after it posted bleak results, while its chief executive rushed to quell what he said were unnecessary bankruptcy fears. Coinbase stock fell 23 per cent after it reported a significant slide in its revenues, which missed analysts’ expectations, as well as a sharp fall in trading volumes in its first-quarter results on Tuesday. The poor results together with concern over a regulatory filing later that day prompted chief executive Brian Armstrong to state on Twitter that Coinbase had “no risk of bankruptcy”. His comment came after a new disclosure suggested customers could be on the hook for claims against the exchange, sparking alarm among Coinbase’s users. According to the filing, the crypto that Coinbase holds in custody for users “could be subject to bankruptcy proceedings and such customers could be treated as our general unsecured creditors”. As a result, users may find the platform “more risky and less attractive”, potentially hurting its financial health, the filing said. But Armstrong rushed to reassure users, apologising for failing to communicate “proactively” when the new wording was added.
“There is some noise about a disclosure we made in our 10Q [regulatory filing] today about how we hold crypto assets,” Armstrong tweeted, adding that rather than being at risk of going bust, the exchange changed its terms to satisfy a regulatory requirement. Analysts at Wedbush noted that Coinbase was “flush with cash” and still investing “aggressively” during the downturn. In its first-quarter results, the company reported greater losses than expected by Wall Street — $430mn compared with the $47mn analysts had estimated — and predicted that trading volumes and user numbers would continue to fall in the current quarter. Coinbase shares have lost 67 per cent of their value since the start of the year, with their price falling below $100 for the first time since the company went public in April last year. At the time of its IPO, Coinbase shares were worth $381. The health of Coinbase’s business has long tracked trends in wider crypto markets, benefiting from a boom in speculative trading by retail investors in the first half of last year. After its public market debut, the company’s profits surpassed more established exchange operators, including CME Group and Intercontinental Exchange during the 2021 bull market. However, recent interest rate rises have sent investors fleeing from the riskiest corners of global financial markets, causing a crypto bear market that has been dubbed the latest “crypto winter”. Bitcoin has fallen sharply recently, dropping below $30,000 for the first time since July earlier this week, amid a broader turmoil in cryptocurrency markets caused by the collapse of stablecoin Terra. Coinbase is also facing regulatory hurdles. On a call with analysts on Tuesday, Armstrong said the company had halted its services in India just a few days after launching in the market because of “informal pressure” from the Reserve Bank of India. Armstrong has previously had run-ins with US regulators, which are currently circling the industry. Last year, he accused the US Securities and Exchange Commission of “sketchy behaviour” after it threatened to sue the company if it launched a particular lending product. Coinbase later shelved plans for the Lend product. Despite the rout, Armstrong and other executives repeatedly sought to reassure investors the downturn could be an opportunity for the company, allowing it to focus on diversifying its business, investing in product innovation and hiring talent. The company recently launched a non-fungible token marketplace and has been exploring areas such as crypto derivatives. Coinbase signed off its shareholder letter with #wagmi, a hashtag popular among the crypto community for “we are all gonna make it”.
