interactive.cheadline: 纳斯达克综合指数下跌3.2%，股票抛售加速
interactive.clongleadbody: 以科技股为主的股指较历史高位下跌近30%，通胀增加了美联储大举加息的可能性。
interactive.cbody:
美国股市周三恢复跌势，此前意外火爆的“核心”通胀数据，提升了市场对积极收紧政策的预期，推动以科技股为主的纳斯达克综合指数(Nasdaq Composite)较创纪录高点下跌近30%。 被视为对加息特别敏感的成长型股票领跌，纳斯达克(Nasdaq)下跌3.2%。蓝筹股标准普尔500指数(S&P 500)昨日收盘下跌1.6%，该指数在早盘一度上涨1.2%。 全球最大经济体4月份消费者价格指数(CPI)同比上涨8.3%，低于3月份的8.5%，但仍处于历史高位。这一数据超出了经济学家预期的降温至8.1%。核心通胀(不包括食品和能源价格，受到经济学家密切关注)的环比变化也超过了预期，为0.6%。 美国劳工部表示，新车、食品、机票和住房成本的不断上涨，是消费者价格上涨的最大驱动因素。 道明证券在一份客户报告中称，“鉴于核心部分的价格涨幅似乎正在扩散，该报告应引起美联储的担忧。”
随着消费者价格飙升，交易员预计，美联储将在今年剩余时间内大幅加息，这令美国短期政府债务承压。 对货币政策尤为敏感的两年期美国国债收益率上升0.03个百分点，至2.64%，一年前还不到0.2%。价格下跌时，收益率上升。 相比之下，受较长期经济趋势推动的10年期美国国债收益率下跌0.06个百分点，至2.93%。 Federated Hermes高级经济学家西尔维亚•达尔•安吉洛(Silvia Dall’angelo)表示：“今天的报告将强化美联储在未来会议上积极收紧政策的决心，明确6月和7月加息(0.5个百分点)的预期。” 期货市场显示，投资者预计，美联储目前设定在0.75%至1%之间的主要利率，将在今年年底前达到2.75%。周三公布通胀数据后，投资者加大了对加息步伐的押注，尽管预期的年底利率仍略低于上周触及的峰值。 欧洲股市和美国股指期货在通胀报告公布前出现上涨，因为投资者认为，随着俄罗斯入侵乌克兰导致能源成本上涨，抑制了消费者支出，价格上涨将显示出更多见顶迹象。 Nuveen首席投资策略师布莱恩•尼克(Brian Nick)表示：“有一种感觉，人们在削减支出，以便给油箱加满油、给家里供暖。上个月的情况显然不是这样。” 投资者和分析师周三警告称，即使通胀现在已经见顶，它仍可能在一段时间内保持在高位，这将推动各国央行继续提高借贷成本。上周，美联储将主要利率上调了0.5个百分点，并暗示将进一步加息。美联储的目标是，一段时间内的平均通胀率为2%。 交易所交易基金提供商WisdomTree研究主管Aneeka Gupta表示：“这不仅与通胀见顶有关，还与未来的轨迹有关。我们认为，要回到央行满意的水平，将是一个漫长的过程。” 其它市场方面，欧洲斯托克600指数上涨1.7%。国际石油基准布伦特原油上涨4.9%，至每桶107.51美元。
interactive.eheadline: Nasdaq Composite slides 3.2% as stock sell-off gathers pace
interactive.elongleadbody: Tech-heavy index down nearly 30% from record as inflation bolsters likelihood of aggressive Fed interest rate rises
interactive.ebody:
US stocks resumed their slide on Wednesday after unexpectedly hot “core” inflation data raised expectations for aggressive policy tightening, pushing the tech-heavy Nasdaq Composite down nearly 30 per cent from its record high. Growth stocks that are seen as particularly sensitive to rising rates led the declines, with the Nasdaq falling 3.2 per cent. The blue-chip S&P 500, which had rallied as much as 1.2 per cent earlier in the trading session, ended the day 1.6 per cent lower. Consumer prices in the world’s largest economy rose at an annual rate of 8.3 per cent in April, down from 8.5 per cent in March but remaining at a historically elevated level. The figure surpassed economists’ expectations for a cool-down to 8.1 per cent. The month-on-month change in core inflation — which excludes food and energy prices and is closely watched by economists — also exceeded forecasts at 0.6 per cent. Rising costs of new cars, food, airline fares and housing were the biggest drivers of the increase in consumer prices, the US labour department said. “The report should be of concern for the Fed given price gains in the core segment appear to be spreading,” TD Securities said in a note to clients.
As consumer prices have surged, traders expect the Fed to raise interest rates aggressively for the rest of this year, which has placed short-term US government debt under pressure. The yield on the two-year Treasury note, which is particularly sensitive to monetary policy, rose 0.03 percentage points to 2.64 per cent, from below 0.2 per cent a year ago. Yields rise when prices fall. In contrast, the 10-year Treasury yield, which is driven by longer-term economic trends, shed 0.06 percentage points to 2.93 per cent. “Today’s report will strengthen the Fed’s resolve to tighten aggressively at its coming meetings, crystallising expectations of [half percentage point] hikes in June and July,” said Silvia Dall’Angelo, senior economist at Federated Hermes. Futures markets indicate investors expect the Fed’s main interest rate, currently set at between 0.75 per cent and 1 per cent, to reach 2.75 per cent by the end of this year. Investors strengthened their bets on the pace of rate rises after Wednesday’s inflation data, though the expected end-of- year rate remained slightly below the peak hit last week. European stocks and US equity futures had rallied before the inflation report as investors assumed that price rises would show more signs of peaking as higher energy costs, driven by Russia’s invasion of Ukraine, depressed consumer spending. “There was a sense that people were cutting back on spending in order to fill up their gas tanks and heat their homes,” said Brian Nick, chief investment strategist at Nuveen. “That clearly wasn’t the case last month.”  Investors and analysts on Wednesday cautioned that even if inflation had now peaked, it could remain elevated for some time, pushing central banks to continue raising borrowing costs. The Fed, which raised its main interest rate by 0.5 percentage points last week and signalled more hikes to come, targets an average inflation rate of 2 per cent over time. “It is not just about inflation peaking, but also the trajectory going forward,” said Aneeka Gupta, research director at exchange traded fund provider WisdomTree. “We believe it is going to be a long, drawn-out process back to levels where central banks are comfortable.” Elsewhere in markets, Europe’s Stoxx 600 share index rose 1.7 per cent. Brent crude, the international oil marker, climbed 4.9 per cent to $107.51 a barrel.

interactive.cheadline: “黑天鹅”警告：俄乌战争引发的金融武器化
interactive.clongleadbody: 金融正被这场冲突武器化——风险管理者成为众矢之的，被置于地缘政治紧张局势之中。
interactive.cbody:
几十年来，金融机构一直在努力应对与冲突有关的制裁和由此产生的风险，包括在2001年美国遭受恐怖袭击，以及2014年莫斯科吞并克里米亚之后出现的制裁。 然而，作为对俄罗斯入侵乌克兰的回应，美国与七国集团(G7)和欧盟(EU)联手推出的经济限制，在规模和范围上都是前所未有的。正如美国总统乔•拜登(Joe Biden)最近在华沙的一次演讲中所言，它们代表着“一种新的经济国策，具有与军事力量相匹敌的破坏力”。 对风险管理人来说，这不仅表明金融如何被用于外交政策的目的，将他们牢牢地置于地缘政治紧张局势的十字路口；这也给他们的企业带来了压力，要求他们正确管理与乌克兰战争有关的风险，以避免落入制裁制度的陷阱。 数据提供商路孚特(Refinitiv)旗下的World-Check公司的客户和第三方风险情报全球主管查尔斯•米努特拉(Charles Minutella)表示：“这给所有系统带来了压力。”World-Check是专门从事制裁和反洗钱风险尽职调查的单位。 金融机构面临的第一个困难是应对数量庞大的制裁和涉及的实体。 在乌克兰战争之前，全球已经有超过300个制裁名单，有不同的语言和格式，涉及不同程度的特殊性和合规性。但现在的情况却截然不同，米努特拉说。“因为俄罗斯而被列入制裁名单的名字数量是巨大的。与此相比，克里米亚事件后实施的制裁只是一个小插曲”。 律师们指出了另一个问题：当新的制裁措施生效时，或者当现有的制裁措施被修改时，往往没有太多的通知可以遵守。 代表英国银行的英国金融(UK Finance)表示，其成员在迅速实施制裁方面拥有丰富的经验和程序。但该公司也表示，英国、欧盟和美国在上市和申请方面“缺乏一致性”，正“导致一个本已复杂的领域变得更加复杂”。 摩根大通首席财务官杰里米•巴纳姆(Jeremy Barnum)在4月份的最新财报电话会议上告诉分析师，该行一直在应对“来自世界各国政府的多重指令，其复杂性前所未有”的经济制裁。 造成这种复杂性的一个原因是，对俄罗斯的制裁已经超越了传统的个人和实体的目标，扩展到整个行业，包括石油和天然气。这使得识别所有受制裁影响的相关公司和子公司的任务更加困难。 此外，英国银行业组织(UK Finance)认为，在欧洲大陆和英国，与俄罗斯有联系的公司的数量正在导致意想不到的后果。例如，那些主要雇用欧盟或英国国民的企业仍然可能触犯为应对冲突而引入的所有权和控制权条款。 这一点在今年3月突显出来。据报道，总部位于英国的健康食品连锁企业荷兰巴雷特(Holland & Barrett)发现，汇丰银行(HSBC)拖延了向债权人支付一笔常规债务，原因是该行正在评估俄罗斯支持的荷兰巴雷特(Holland & Barrett)母公司LetterOne的制裁状况。

此份报告披露了更多信息

瑞士信贷承认宽松的做法导致了丑闻的发生

远期危险需要聪明的变通方法

银行面临碳排放的拷问

风险管理人如何在“完美风暴”中生存下来

加密货币的“狂野西部”时代即将落幕

对于那些向已经或可能被制裁的公司提供贷款的银行，还有其他复杂的问题。安理国际律师事务所(Allen & Overy)表示，这些问题可能包括：如果一个未受制裁的借款人在一家不再被允许使用Swift的受制裁银行开立了银行账户，那么该借款人是否还能使用支付系统--比如比利时的金融信息传递系统Swift。 除此之外，金融机构还必须应对网络风险的上升。今年4月，美国、澳大利亚、加拿大、新西兰和英国当局在一份联合咨询通知中警告称，“不断演变的情报表明，俄罗斯政府正在探索潜在网络攻击的选项”。他们还指出，一些网络犯罪组织承诺支持俄罗斯。 美国网络安全公司CrowdStrike高级副总裁亚当•迈耶斯(Adam Meyers)表示：“银行将需要认真对待这些威胁，因为这些金融机构现在是这场冲突的一部分。” 他指出了三种主要的网络威胁：国家(这里指的是俄罗斯)利用勒索软件窃取信息的“计算机网络攻击”;寻求获取经济利益的黑客犯罪;有意识形态动机的“黑客活动分子”试图泄露敏感信息，给金融机构造成舆论危机。 迈耶斯说，一些银行可能已经变得更容易受到攻击，这是为了实现远程工作而对其网络架构进行更改的结果，这导致防火墙有时不如以前有效。 这意味着他们必须更多地关注谁能在组织内访问数据。“银行需要一种‘零信任’防御策略，但许多机构都没有这么做。这是我们越来越多地在临时演讲台上谈论的事情之一。 与网络威胁一样，乌克兰战争的连锁反应加剧了金融机构在乌克兰战争之前就存在的其他风险。其中最主要的是大宗商品价格波动。这给旨在确保平稳运行的金融市场基础设施带来了压力。 清算所使用被称为保证金的金融缓冲器，以确保即使一方违约也能完成交易，受到的影响尤其大。 市场参与者在清算所提交的保证金数额是为了承受重大的市场波动。然而，最近镍等大宗商品价格的异常波动，引发了人们的担忧，即冲击事件正变得越来越频繁。 这对如何设定保证金以及最终如何管理市场风险都有潜在的重大影响。 美国期货业协会(Futures Industry Association)主席沃尔特•卢肯(Walt Lukken)表示：“我们仍然认为，保证金是覆盖潜在风险的重要方式。期货业协会的成员包括期货交易所、清算所和大宗商品交易商。”但似乎会有更多的‘黑天鹅’事件发生，我们需要找到方法来预测。”
interactive.eheadline: Ukraine war reveals ‘black swan’ danger
interactive.elongleadbody: Finance is being weaponised by the conflict — placing risk managers in the crosshairs of geopolitical tensions
interactive.ebody:
Financial institutions have been grappling with conflict-related sanctions and resultant risks for decades, including those that emerged in the wake of the 2001 terrorist attacks on the US and Moscow’s annexation of Crimea in 2014. Yet the economic restrictions that the US, acting with the G7 and the EU, has rolled out in response to Russia’s invasion of Ukraine are unprecedented in scale and scope. They represent “a new kind of economic statecraft with the power to inflict damage that rivals military might”, as US president Joe Biden put it, in a recent speech in Warsaw. To risk managers, this not only signals how finance is being weaponised for foreign policy aims, placing them firmly in the crosshairs of geopolitical tensions; it also piles pressure on their businesses to get the risk management associated with the war in Ukraine right — to avoid falling foul of sanctions regimes. “It’s providing stress on all systems,” says Charles Minutella, global head of customer and third-party risk intelligence at World-Check, a unit of data provider Refinitiv that specialises in due diligence for sanctions and anti-money laundering risk. The first difficulty for financial institutions is dealing with the sheer number of sanctions and entities involved. There were already over 300 sanctions lists globally, in different languages and formats, involving different levels of specificity and compliance, before the Ukraine war. But the picture now is rather different, says Minutella: “The volume of names being added to sanctions lists because of Russia is monumental. The sanctions put in place after Crimea were a blip compared to this.” Lawyers point out another problem: that, when new sanctions come into force, or when existing ones are amended, there is often not much notice to comply. UK Finance, which represents banks in the UK, says its members have considerable experience and processes in place to implement sanctions swiftly. But it also says that “lack of alignment” on listings and the application of them from the UK, EU and US is “causing an already complicated area to become even more complex”. Jeremy Barnum, JPMorgan’s chief financial officer, told analysts on the bank’s latest earnings call in April that it had been dealing with economic sanctions “of unprecedented complexity with multiple directives from governments around the world”. One reason for the complexity is that sanctions against Russia have been extended beyond the traditional targets of individuals and entities to whole sectors, including oil and natural gas. This makes the task of identifying all the relevant companies and subsidiaries affected by sanctions still harder.
Sanctions against Russia have expanded to include oil and natural gas.
Moreover, UK Finance argues that the number of companies in continental Europe and the UK with Russian links is leading to unintended consequences. For example, businesses that employ mainly EU or UK nationals can still fall foul of ownership and control clauses introduced in response to the conflict. This was highlighted in March when UK-based health food chain Holland & Barrett reportedly found that a routine debt payment to creditors was held up by HSBC because the bank was reviewing the sanctions status of LetterOne, Holland & Barrett’s Russian-backed owner.

Remote jeopardy calls for smart workarounds

Banks face grilling over carbon emissions

How risk managers can survive a ‘perfect storm’

The sun starts to set on Wild West days of crypto

For banks that have lent to companies that have been, or may be, sanctioned, there are other complex questions. Allen & Overy, a law firm, says these can include whether a borrower that has not been sanctioned can still access payment systems — such as Swift, the Belgium-based financial messaging system — if its own bank account is held at a sanctioned bank that is no longer permitted to use Swift. On top of this, financial institutions must contend with elevated cyber risks. In April, authorities in the US, Australia, Canada, New Zealand and the UK warned in a joint advisory notice that “evolving intelligence indicates that the Russian government is exploring options for potential cyber attacks”. They also noted that some cyber crime groups had pledged support for Russia. “Banks are going to need to take these threats seriously because these financial institutions are now a component of this conflict,” says Adam Meyers, a senior vice-president at CrowdStrike, a US-based cyber security company. He identifies three main types of cyber threat: “computer network exploitation” by nation states — in this case, Russia — using ransomware to steal information; criminal hackers seeking to extract financial gain; and ideologically motivated “hacktivists” attempting to leak sensitive information to cause embarrassment for financial institutions. Meyers says that some banks may have become more vulnerable as a result of changes to their network architecture that were implemented to enable remote working — with the result that firewalls are sometimes not as effective as before. This means they have to pay more attention to who has access to data within the organisation. “Banks need a ‘zero trust’ defensive strategy but a lot of organisations aren’t doing this. It’s one of the things we are increasingly on our soapbox about,” Meyers says. As with cyber threats, other risks for financial institutions that existed before the Ukraine war have been exacerbated by the knock-on effects of the conflict. Chief among them is commodity price volatility. This has strained the financial market infrastructure that is designed to ensure smooth operations. Clearing houses, which use financial buffers known as margin to ensure a trade is completed even if one party defaults, are particularly affected. The amount of margin posted at a clearing house by market participants is designed to withstand significant market volatility. Yet recent exceptional swings in the prices of commodities, such as nickel, have prompted concern that shock events are becoming more frequent. This has potentially significant implications for how margin is set and, ultimately, how market risk is managed. Walt Lukken, president of the Futures Industry Association, whose members include futures exchanges, clearing houses and commodity traders, says: “We still think that margin is an important way to cover potential risk. But there appear to be more of these ‘black swan’ events happening and we need to find ways to anticipate that.”

冲突的焦点转向顿巴斯地区是在俄罗斯在战争的第一阶段未能占领基辅之后发生的。俄罗斯人受挫于各种因素，包括地理环境、攻击者的失误和现代武器--以及乌克兰对智能手机和泡沫垫的巧妙运用。

interactive.cheadline: 通货膨胀追踪：各国努力应对物价上涨的最新数据
interactive.clongleadbody: 英国《金融时报》分析了全球消费者价格和房价的上涨，并评估了这种趋势可能持续多久。
interactive.cbody:
许多国家的通货膨胀已经达到几十年来的最高水平，俄罗斯入侵乌克兰推高了能源和食品价格，挤压了家庭的实际收入。 由冲突引发的价格压力--以及增长降级--已经增加。一些经济学家担心会回到1970年代的长期通货膨胀和衰退环境。
高通货膨胀仍然具有广泛的地域性。亚洲的消费者价格增长甚至已经开始上升，这个地区直到最近还基本上是全世界模式的一个例外。
正如经常阅读的读者所知，本页定期更新全球消费者价格通胀的可视化描述，包括经济学家对未来的预期。全球大多数最大经济体的最新数据令人担忧，价格压力飙升至数十年来的最高水平。
甚至在俄罗斯入侵乌克兰之前，能源价格的上涨就推动了许多国家的通货膨胀。每日数据显示，在一场冲突导致欧洲和美国禁止(或正在考虑禁止)俄罗斯能源出口后，压力最近如何加剧。
共识经济学(Consensus Economics)调查的主要预测机构稳步上调了2022年和2023年的通胀预期。 高通胀还从能源领域蔓延到许多其他消费品领域，尤其是在那些需求强劲到足以让企业转嫁成本上升的国家。
不断上涨的消费者价格对各国央行构成挑战，尤其是将价格稳定目标设定在2%左右的七国集团(G7)国家。为了实现这一目标，各国央行可以调整货币政策，以抑制需求。但通过提高借贷成本来抑制需求，可能会加剧物价上涨对实际收入造成的挤压。
物价上涨限制了家庭在商品和服务上的支出。对于不太富裕的人来说，这可能会导致他们难以负担食物和住所等基本生活必需品。 主食商品的日常数据，如早餐原料的批发价格，提供了一个所面临压力的最新指标。在发展中国家，这些配料的批发价格对最终的食品价格有较大的影响；食品也占家庭支出的较大份额。
另一个值得关注的问题是资产价格，尤其是房屋价格。 在疫情期间，由于超宽松的货币政策、在家工作的人希望有更多的空间，以及政府的收入支持计划，许多国家的家庭收入飙升。
政策制定者和经济学家之间的关键辩论仍然集中在高通胀将持续多久。几个月前，许多人预计利率飙升的时间太短，货币政策不会产生太大影响，因为加息的影响需要时间才能渗透到经济体中。然而，乌克兰的冲突——以及有迹象表明通胀压力已变得更为广泛——加剧了人们的担忧，即通胀的粘性将比预期的更大。 市场对未来五年通胀的预期普遍上升，表明企业和家庭正在经历的痛苦很可能 将持续下去。
interactive.eheadline: Global inflation tracker: see how your country compares on rising prices
interactive.elongleadbody: Russia’s invasion has raised prices for everything from energy to wheat, adding to inflationary pressures worldwide
interactive.ebody:
Inflation has hit its highest level in decades in many countries, with Russia’s invasion of Ukraine pushing up energy and food prices and squeezing households’ real incomes. Price pressures — and growth downgrades — have increased, triggered by the conflict. Some economists fear a return to the chronic inflation and recessionary environment of the 1970s.
High inflation remains geographically broad-based. Consumer price growth has even started rising in Asia, a region that until recently had largely been an exception to the worldwide pattern.
As regular readers will know, this page provides a regularly updated visual narrative of consumer price inflation around the world, including economists’ expectations for the future. The latest figures for most of the world’s largest economies make for worrying reading, with price pressures surging to the highest level in many decades.
The rise in energy prices drove inflation in many countries even before Russia invaded Ukraine. Daily data show how the pressure has recently intensified on the back of a conflict that has led to Europe and the US banning, or considering bans, on Russian energy exports.
Leading forecasters polled by Consensus Economics have steadily revised up their expected inflation figures for 2022 and 2023. Higher inflation is also spreading beyond energy to many other consumer items, especially in countries where demand is strong enough for businesses to pass on higher costs.
Rising consumer prices present a challenge for central banks, not least those in G7 countries that have a price stability target of about 2 per cent. To reach that goal, central banks can adjust monetary policy to curb demand. But choking off demand by raising borrowing costs could exacerbate the squeeze on real incomes that has resulted from higher prices.
Rising prices limit what households can spend on goods and services. For the less well-off, that could lead to a struggle to afford basics, such as food and shelter. Daily data on staple goods, such as the wholesale price of breakfast ingredients, provide an up-to-date indicator of the pressures faced. In developing countries, the wholesale cost of these ingredients has a larger impact on final food prices; food also accounts for a larger share of household spending.
Another point of concern is asset prices, especially for houses. These soared in many countries during the pandemic, boosted by ultra loose monetary policy, homeworkers’ desire for more space and government income-support schemes.
The key debate among policymakers and economists remains focused on how long high inflation will last. A few months ago, many expected the surge to be too shortlived for monetary policy to have much of an impact, with the effect of higher rates taking time to seep through into economies. However, the conflict in Ukraine — along with signs that inflationary pressures have become more broad based — have exacerbated fears that inflation will prove stickier than hoped. Markets’ expectations for inflation over the next five years are generally rising, suggesting support for the view that the pain businesses and households are experiencing will endure.

interactive.cheadline: 互联网金融真的更代表未来吗？
interactive.clongleadbody: 在股价暴跌之际，“先买后付”的项目变得更加依赖贷款。
interactive.cbody:
马克斯•莱夫钦(Max Levchin)创立Affirm Holdings的时候，他认为，与老牌贷款机构相比，年轻人更愿意从硅谷初创企业贷款。 “消费者，尤其是千禧一代和Z世代，已经对金融机构失去了信任，”莱夫钦去年告诉投资者，“越来越喜欢更灵活、更创新的数字支付解决方案，而不是传统的信贷支付选择。” 他的愿景使总部位于旧金山的Affirm成为最大的”先买后付“公司之一，该公司允许购物者在网上购买衣服、电子产品和其他商品时获得无担保分期付款贷款。去年上市后，投资者将这家亏损的公司赋予了470亿美元的最高市值，对它的估值更像是一个华丽的科技颠覆者，而不是一个呆板的贷款人。 如今，随着科技股下滑、利率上升，投资者开始重新考虑。 该公司的市值已跌至50亿美元，此前其股票从去年11月的高点下跌了89%。根据彭博社对分析师的调查，周四的季度业绩预计将显示净亏损1.56亿美元，收入为3.45亿美元。一些人说，Affirm与传统金融机构的相似性比它的账面数字更好看。
戴维森(D A Davidson)的分析师克里斯·布伦德勒(Chris Brendler)说，“这类混合金融科技股，在某种程度上，它们的交易方式与科技股类似，因为它们增长非常快，而且它们的金融业务不会引发任何问题。但如果你开始出现更高的亏损或融资问题，它们就会开始表现得像金融类股。” Affirm对零售商的宣传很简单：通过允许客户分次付款购买商品，有时甚至不计利息，他们将销售更多产品。 零售商向Affirm支付“商家折扣费”，实际上是购买价格的几个百分点的佣金。2020年，该公司近60%的收入来自于这种费用。 疫情期间，Affirm最大的商家客户是健身自行车制造商Peloton，该公司的销售额目前正在下降。 但在与亚马逊和沃尔玛等大型零售商签署合作协议后，Affirm的业务组合已经开始发生变化。这些公司有足够的实力，不必向商家支付折扣费用。 相反，现在Affirm的大部分收入来自于其作为贷款人的功能：通过证券化或向第三方买家(如保险公司)出售贷款，或者通过其资产负债表上的资产赚取利息收入。在最近公布的季度中，该公司一半以上的收入来自利息收入和贷款销售收益。
Affirm表示，它仍然致力于发展其产生费用的业务，作为建立“不同产品的菜单，以满足消费者和商家对购物车大小、类别和付款条件的需求”的战略的一部分。 Affirm表示：“这是一个差异化的关键点，它使Affirm在这个大规模和快速增长的行业中成为领导者，因为消费者继续寻求灵活的选择，按照自己的节奏支付。" 与传统银行不同，Affirm不持有消费者存款，而是依靠”仓库“信贷额度。Cross River银行是一家位于新泽西州的初创公司，由顶级风险投资公司支持，负责发放Affirm的贷款，而现购现付小组则负责管理与客户的关系。 Affirm还通过证券化，或将贷款打包成债券出售的方式实现了增长，其中一些贷款被保留在自己的账面上。出售债券可以产生现金，用于未来贷款，而投资者对这类债券的兴趣仍然很高。 根据Affirm汇编的数据，两年前，该公司的贷款没有一笔是通过证券化融资的。到最近一个季度，Affirm 60亿美元投资组合的三分之一已被打包成债券。
消费者通过Affirm在网上购买衣服、电子产品和其他商品时，可以获得无担保的分期贷款
从手续费到贷款和利息收入的转变，使Affirm的核销过程成为新的焦点。潜在的信用损失不仅减少了公司保留的贷款的账面价值，而且还减少了它在二级市场上可以获得的收益。 根据Affirm的数据，在2020年最后一个季度，仅有1.44%的贷款出现4至29天的拖欠或延迟付款。4个季度后，这一数字升至3%以上。在最近一个季度，该集团为潜在贷款损失拨备的准备金占其贷款账目的比例达到6.5%，高于2021年年中的5.2%。向消费者收取的利率可能高达30%。 “虽然我们同意Affirm发挥着重要的支付功能，但我们认为，Affirm实际上更像是一家贷款机构，而不是一家支付公司，”Stephens的分析师文森特·凯恩蒂克(Vincent Caintic)最近写道。 Affirm最近的毛利润率(包括信贷成本)达到了4%，尽管运营成本和日常开支已经侵蚀了净利润。 然而，怀疑人士指出，过去两年，该公司的爆炸式增长是在失业率下降、美国消费者拥有大量政府刺激资金之际实现的。 做空者和对冲基金Kynikos Associates的创始人吉姆•查诺斯(Jim Chanos)一直在批评Affirm和其他向大银行发起挑战的金融科技初创企业。 “每次，都有一群互联网的贷款人试图 说服市场，他们有更好的模型来评估信用度。 他们只是把贷款给了不该给的人。 直到你在信用周期中经历低迷之前，才能看到这一点，”查诺斯说。
华尔街也在关注其商业模式的细节。今年3月，在债券市场动荡之际，Affirm取消了一笔5亿美元的融资交易，该交易原本计划用于向客户提供未来贷款。 在最近的一次投资者活动中，Affirm首席财务官迈克尔•林福德(Michael Linford)淡化了这一举动，称撤销交易是“强劲的迹象，而不是疲软的迹象”。 他补充说：“我们对这项业务感觉非常好，并认为我们不需要试图阻挠交易。” 在今年3月提交的一份证券文件中，Affirm表示，它仍拥有近100亿美元的承诺资本，足以支持短期贷款。该公司表示，如果经济开始恶化，它可以迅速调整其贷款政策，特别是因为其贷款的期限并不长，如汽车或房屋的贷款。 林福德在3月的投资者会议上表示：“但在经济衰退的前期，也就是当情况开始恶化时，假设失业率大幅上升，那么我们将经历更大的损失。然而，鉴于我们的资产持续时间较短，我们认为我们能够对这个资产评估进行很大程度的重新定位。” 哈里特·阿格纽(Harriet Agnew)伦敦补充报道
interactive.eheadline: Affirm struggles to convince investors of fintech bona fides
interactive.elongleadbody: ‘Buy now pay later’ group becomes more reliant on loans amid plummeting share price
interactive.ebody:
Max Levchin founded Affirm Holdings in the belief that younger people were more open to borrowing from Silicon Valley start-ups than established lenders. “Consumers, particularly millennials and Gen Z, have lost trust in financial institutions,” Levchin told investors last year, and “increasingly prefer more flexible and innovative digital payment solutions in lieu of traditional credit payment options”. His vision has made San Francisco-based Affirm one of the biggest “buy now, pay later” companies, which allow shoppers to obtain unsecured instalment loans when they buy clothes, electronics and other goods online. Investors bestowed the lossmaking company with a peak market capitalisation of $47bn after it went public last year, valuing it more like a flashy tech disrupter than a stodgy lender. Now, as tech shares slide and interest rates rise, investors are having second thoughts. The company’s market capitalisation has fallen to $5bn after its stock declined 89 per cent from a high last November. Quarterly results due on Thursday are expected to show a net loss of $156mn on $345mn of revenue, according to a Bloomberg poll of analysts. Some say Affirm bears a closer resemblance to a traditional financial institution than its digital sheen would suggest.
“These kind of hybrid financial technology stocks, they kind of trade like tech stocks when they’re growing really fast and the financial side of their business doesn’t cause any problems,” said Chris Brendler, an analyst at D A Davidson. “But if you start having higher losses or funding problems, that’s when they start to perform like financials.” Affirm’s pitch to retailers has been simple: by allowing the customers to split up payments for merchandise, sometimes without interest, they will sell more products. Retailers pay Affirm “merchant discount fees”, effectively a commission of a few percentage points of a purchase price. In 2020 nearly 60 per cent of the company’s revenue was derived from such fees. Affirm’s largest merchant during the pandemic was Peloton, the stationary bike maker whose sales are now in decline. But Affirm’s business mix has begun to shift after it signed partnerships with large retailers such as Amazon and Walmart — companies with enough heft to avoid having to pay merchant discount fees. Instead, the majority of Affirm’s revenue is now coming from its function as a lender: by selling loans either through securitisations or to third-party buyers such as insurance companies, or by earning interest income for the assets that it keeps on its own balance sheet. In its most recent reported quarter, more than half of the revenue came from interest income and gains on the sale of loans.
Affirm said it was still committed to growing its fee-generating businesses as part of a strategy to build “a menu of different products to meet consumer and merchant needs across cart sizes, categories, and payment terms”. “This is a key point of differentiation that strongly positions Affirm to build upon our momentum as a leader in a massive and fast-growing industry as consumers continue seeking flexible options to pay at their own pace,” Affirm said. Unlike a traditional bank, Affirm does not hold consumer deposits and instead relies on “warehouse” lines of credit. Cross River Bank, a A New Jersey-based start-up backed by top venture capital firms, originates Affirm’s loans, while the buy-now-pay-later group then manages the relationship with the customer. Affirm has also grown through securitisations, or bundling loans to sell as bonds, some of which it retains on its own books. Selling on debt generates cash to make future loans, and investor appetite for this kind of paper remains high. Two years ago, none of Affirm’s loans were funded through securitisation, according to data compiled by the company. By the most recent quarter, a third of Affirm’s $6bn portfolio had been bundled into bonds.
Shoppers are able to obtain unsecured instalment loans when they buy clothes, electronics and other goods online via Affirm
The shift from fees to lending and interest income has put new focus on Affirm’s underwriting process. Potential credit losses not only reduce the carrying value of loans that the company retains, but also the gains it can earn in secondary markets. In the last quarter of 2020, just 1.44 per cent of Affirm loans were marked four to 29 days delinquent or late in payment, according to company data. Four quarters later, that figure had edged up to more than 3 per cent. In its most recent quarter, the amount of allowances that the group sets aside for potential loan losses had reached 6.5 per cent of its loan book, up from 5.2 per cent in mid-2021. Interest rates charged to consumers can be as high as 30 per cent. “While we agree that Affirm serves an important payments function, we contend that Affirm is actually more a lender than a payments company,” Vincent Caintic, an analyst at Stephens, recently wrote. Affirm recently reached its gross profit margin of 4 per cent, which includes credit costs, even as operating costs and overhead have chewed up net income. Sceptics, however, have noted the company’s explosive growth in the past two years came at a time of falling unemployment and when US consumers were flush with government stimulus cash. Jim Chanos, the short seller and founder of hedge fund Kynikos Associates, has been a critic of Affirm and other financial tech starts-ups that have taken on big banks. “Every time, a group of internet-based lenders tries to convince the market that they have a better model to assess creditworthiness. They’re simply extending credit to people they shouldn’t be. And we won’t see this until you go through a downturn in the credit cycle,” Chanos said.
Wall Street is also focusing on the details of its business model. In March, at a time of turmoil in the bond market, Affirm pulled a $500mn financing transaction that it planned to use to fund future loans to customers. At a recent investor event, Affirm’s chief financial officer, Michael Linford, played down the move, saying the withdrawn transaction was “a sign of strength, not a sign of weakness”. He added: “We felt really good about the business and thought like we didn’t need to try to jam a deal.” In a securities filing in March, Affirm said it still had nearly $10bn in committed capital that was more than adequate to support near-term loans. If the economy began to deteriorate, the company said it could quickly adjust its lending policies, particularly because its loans are not extended for long periods such as those for cars or homes. “But on the front end of a recession, that is to say as things start to get worse and deteriorate, assuming there’s a meaningful unemployment surge associated with that, then we would experience higher losses,” Linford said at a March investor conference. “However, given the short duration of our asset, we think we’d be able to reposition the funnel quite a bit.” Additional reporting by Harriet Agnew in London

interactive.clongleadbody: 比特币价格周一下跌多达5%，至32,630美元左右，现在比去年11月达到的峰值低50%。
interactive.cbody:
纳斯达克综合指数(Nasdaq Composite index)目前下跌了3%，科技股又经历了可怕的一天，但如果你也一直在投资加密货币，这将是双重打击(巴厘岛所有的加密货币海滩爱好者醒来时都要面临这个坏消息)。 比特币价格周一下跌多达5%，至32,630美元左右，现在比去年11月达到的峰值低50%。前500名数字资产在这段时间内也暴跌了50%。据Scott Chipolina报道，自那时以来，加密货币的市值已经下降了16亿美元，利率上升使投资者逃离了全球金融市场中风险最大的角落。 韦德布什证券(Wedbush Securities)策略师丹尼尔•艾夫斯(Daniel Ives)表示：“这是所有资产类别的风险规避，包括加密货币。”他补充称，“无处可躲”。 比特币的交易处于2021年7月以来的最低水平，但整个加密市场的损失更大。追踪比特币以外前五大货币的FT 威尔特郡测算表，已从近期高点下跌近70%。曾经快速增长的货币，如Solana，被标榜为以太坊网络的替代品，现已经迅速贬值。 一些公司受到加密货币的影响，上市股票也出现了下滑。由加密货币倡导者迈克尔-赛勒(Michael Saylor)领导的微策略(MicroStrategy)今年迄今已经下跌了55%。Coinbase在2022年下跌了65%，周一跌破了100美元，这是该交易所去年4月在纽约上市以来的首次跌破100美元。 此次回调还突显出，比特币和其他加密货币的表现与美国股市密切相关。数据提供商Kaiko的数据显示，比特币与纳斯达克综合指数之间的关联度已达到创纪录高点。纳斯达克综合指数是一个以美国大型科技公司为权重的指标。 “一些投资者把加密货币当作对冲通货膨胀的工具，但它的交易就像纳斯达克的连体婴儿，”艾夫斯说。

互联网五大要闻

1. 美国制裁加密货币混合行为 加密货币也因其用于洗钱而受到当局的压力。美国财政部周五公布了针对Blender.io的措施。该公司帮助一个由朝鲜赞助的黑客组织清洗价值2050万美元的“非法所得”。这笔钱来自于有史以来最大的加密货币抢劫案之一。 2. 半导体制造商看起来仍然很时髦 Lex表示，科技股可能在下跌，芯片制造商继续创造强劲的业绩。德国英飞凌(Infineon)周一紧跟趋势，公布第二季度利润(温和)超过预期，并将全年销售预期从130亿欧元上调至130亿至140亿欧元。英飞凌在汽车行业的专业性——超过五分之二的销量——意味着它能从电动和辅助驾驶汽车的健康交易中受益。 3.NSO在合法性问题上故意拖延 据代表以色列间谍软件公司NSO Group所有者的顾问说，该公司对其是否合法运营的问题置之不理。伯克利研究集团(Berkeley Research Group)告诉欧盟立法者，他们对NSO“合法性”的调查“被NSO集团的管理团队忽视和/或挫败”了。 4. 穆克什·安巴尼(Mukesh Ambani)推动电子商务交易 印度大亨穆克什-安巴尼的信实工业公司(Reliance Industries)在第一季度的投资创下了三年来的新高，达到10笔交易。其中总价值约为3.3亿美元的两项投资，用于快递初创公司Dunzo和机器人公司Addverb，以加强信实零售公司的电子商务平台。预计Addverb将帮助信实实现仓库自动化。 5. 科技评论：Snapchat的教训，亚马逊的流媒体 伊莱恩·摩尔敦促埃隆·马斯克从Snapchat不断变化的命运中吸取教训。目前，这款应用的用户数量比Twitter多1亿，其用户基础的增长速度也快于Facebook。克洛伊·科尼什(Chloe Cornish)写了一篇关于流媒体为争夺印度喜爱电影且对价格敏感的消费者而进行大战的文章。在一场引人注目的企业活动上，全球媒体企业似乎对Netflix最近的羞辱毫不在意。

科技前一周

周二。在美国，陷入困境的网络健身公司Peloton发布第一季度报告，此前有报道称其正寻求出售公司20%的股份。在日本，索尼和任天堂宣布季度业绩。埃隆-马斯克在伦敦举行的FT未来汽车峰会上发言。点击这里注册观看。 周三：华特迪士尼公司(Walt Disney)预计将公布第二季度收入增长，这得益于其流媒体服务Disney+的注册人数增加。亚马逊支持的电动卡车和SUV制造商Rivian也计划在股市收盘后公布业绩。Airbnb将宣布其2022年的产品更新，其中可能包括iPhone设计师乔尼·艾夫爵士的改进建议。 周四：日本科技集团软银(SoftBank)公布了收益，台湾代工制造商富士康(Foxconn)也公布了收益。其结果将在一定程度上显示出科技供应链，以及中国的疫情封锁是否会进一步破坏形势，打击全球消费电子产品制造商等问题。在美国，存储芯片制造商美光(Micron)举行了投资者日。 周五：东芝将在季度财报中公布私有化计划的最新进展。

技术工具- Briiv空气过滤器

杰米•沃特斯(Jamie Waters)写道，售价299英镑的Briiv空气滤清器是一个更有活力的玻璃容器。这是一个透明的罐子，里面装满了郁郁葱葱的微型地衣森林。经过驯鹿苔、椰壳纤维和活性炭等的内部过滤，它可以呼出如北极般洁净的空气。测试表明，它能在短短一小时内有效改善36平方米房间的空气质量，其净化空气的效果与3043株室内植物相同。
interactive.eheadline: Crypto crumbles as rates rise
interactive.elongleadbody: NSO stonewalls, Mukesh Ambani amps ecommerce, Briiv’s tiny forest
interactive.ebody:
While tech stocks are having another dire day, with the Nasdaq Composite index currently down 3 per cent, it’s a double whammy if you’ve also been investing in cryptocurrencies (and bad news for all those crypto beach bums in Bali when they wake up). Bitcoin fell as much as 5 per cent to around $32,630 on Monday and is now 50 per cent below its peak reached in November last year. The top 500 digital assets have also tumbled 50 per cent in that time. Cryptocurrencies have shed $1.6tn in market value since then, reports Scott Chipolina, with interest rate rises sending investors fleeing from the riskiest corners of global financial markets. “This is a risk off across all asset classes, including crypto,” said Daniel Ives, strategist at Wedbush Securities, who added that there is “nowhere to hide”.
Bitcoin is trading at its lowest level since July 2021, but losses are even deeper across the broader crypto market. An FT Wiltshire gauge tracking the top five coins, excluding bitcoin, has fallen almost 70 per cent from its recent high. Once fast-growing coins such as Solana, billed as an alternative to the Ethereum network, have rapidly deflated in value. Listed shares in crypto-exposed companies have slumped as well. MicroStrategy, which is led by crypto advocate Michael Saylor, has dropped 55 per cent so far this year. Coinbase has dropped 65 per cent in 2022, falling below $100 on Monday for the first time since the exchange went public in New York last April. The pullback also highlights how the performance of bitcoin and other cryptocurrencies is tightly linked with the US stock market. The correlation between bitcoin and the Nasdaq Composite, a gauge that is weighted towards America’s big tech companies, has reached record highs, according to data provider Kaiko. “Some investors are playing crypto like a hedge against inflation, but it’s trading like the Nasdaq’s Siamese twin,” said Ives.

The Internet of (Five) Things

1. Crypto-mixing sanctioned by US Crypto is also under pressure from the authorities over its use in money-laundering. The US Treasury department on Friday unveiled measures against Blender.io for its role in helping a hacking group sponsored by North Korea launder $20.5mn in “illicit proceeds” from one of the biggest-ever crypto heists. 2. Semiconductor makers still look chipper Tech stocks may be falling but chipmakers continue to roll out strong results, says Lex. Germany’s Infineon on Monday was bang on trend, reporting a (modest) profit beat in the second quarter and raising full-year sales guidance from €13bn to €13bn-€14bn. Infineon’s auto industry specialisation — more than two-fifths of sales — means it benefits from healthy trading in electric and assisted-driving vehicles. 3. NSO stonewalls over legality Israeli spyware company NSO Group has stonewalled questions over whether it is operating legally, according to consultants acting on behalf of the controversial company’s owners. Berkeley Research Group has told EU lawmakers that its inquiries about NSO’s “lawfulness” have been “ignored and/or frustrated by NSO Group’s management team”. 4. Mukesh Ambani amps ecommerce deals Investments by Indian tycoon Mukesh Ambani’s Reliance Industries hit a three-year high in the first quarter at 10 deals. Two, worth around $330mn combined, were to strengthen Reliance Retail’s ecommerce platform, with investments in delivery start-up Dunzo and robotics company Addverb, which is expected to help Reliance automate its warehouses. 5. Tech comment: Snapchat’s lessons, Amazon streaming on Elaine Moore urges Elon Musk to learn from the changing fortunes of Snapchat. The app now has 100mn more users than Twitter and its customer base is growing faster than Facebook’s. Chloe Cornish writes about the streaming battles for India’s movie-loving, price-conscious consumers. At a glamorous corporate event, global media businesses seem unfazed by the recent humbling of Netflix.

Tech week ahead

Tuesday: In the US, the struggling networked fitness company Peloton reports on its first quarter, amid reports it is looking to sell a 20 per cent stake in the company. In Japan, Sony and Nintendo announce quarterly results. Elon Musk addresses the FT Future of the Car Summit in London. Register to watch by clicking here. Wednesday: Walt Disney is expected to post a rise in second-quarter revenues, benefiting from more sign-ups to its Disney+ streaming service. Rivian, the electric truck and SUV maker backed by Amazon is also scheduled to report after the market close. Airbnb is announcing its 2022 product update, which may include improvements suggested by iPhone designer Sir Jony Ive. Thursday: Japanese tech conglomerate SoftBank reports earnings, as does Taiwanese contract manufacturer Foxconn. Its results will give some indication of the extent of problems in the tech supply chain and whether Covid lockdowns in China will further undermine the situation, hitting consumer electronics manufacturers worldwide. In the US, memory chipmaker Micron holds its investor day. Friday: An update on its take-private plans is expected from Toshiba when it reports quarterly results.

Tech tools — Briiv air filter

Briiv air filter, £299
Briiv’s £299 air filter is a terrarium with added oomph, writes Jamie Waters. A clear jar filled with a miniature forest of lush lichen, its fan exhales Arctic-clean air from its reindeer moss, coconut-husk fibres and activated carbon interior. Tests show it effectively improves the air quality in a 36 sq m room in just an hour and has the same air-scrubbing impact as 3,043 houseplants.

interactive.cheadline: 拉加德明确表示欧洲央行将在7月加息
interactive.clongleadbody: 经济学家现在认为，欧洲央行十多年来的首次加息已成定局。
interactive.cbody:
克里斯蒂娜•拉加德(Christine Lagarde)发出信号，她将支持欧洲央行(ECB)在7月上调主要利率，这使得经济学家们宣称，10多年来的首次加息几乎已成定局。

这位欧洲央行行长周三在斯洛文尼亚发表讲话时表示，她预计该行将在“第三季度初”停止通过购买债券扩大资产负债表，然后在此后“某个时间”加息，“可能只是几周的时间”。

拉加德补充称，为了确保企业和家庭对未来通胀的预期不会进一步上升、以至于考验央行信誉，“证明我们致力于价格稳定的行动”至关重要。欧元区4月份通胀率达到创纪录的7.5%，几乎是欧洲央行2%目标的4倍。

越来越多的欧洲央行管理委员会成员呼吁，在欧洲央行7月21日的政策会议上将存款利率上调25个基点，拉加德的言论表明她支持这些成员。存款利率目前为- 0.5%。2014年存款利率被下调，以帮助应对欧洲债务危机，自那以来一直处于负值。

经济学家们一直在提前央行何时加息的预测。瑞银(UBS)的莱因哈德•克鲁泽(Reinhard Cluse)周三预测，欧洲央行将分7次在明年年底之前上调存款利率至1.25%，7月份加息25个基点将是其中的第一次。百达资产管理公司(Pictet Asset Management)策略师弗雷德里克•杜克洛泽(Frederik Ducrozet)在Twitter上表示，欧洲央行7月加息似乎是“板上钉钉的事情”。

欧洲央行官员越来越担心，俄罗斯入侵乌克兰的影响将使通胀率在更长时间内保持在高位，并加深消费者和企业对物价上涨的预期。

拉加德表示，这场战争“可能会加速两项正在进行的结构性变化，在过渡期间，这两项变化可能会导致进一步的负面供应冲击和成本压力。”

她表示，欧洲央行将于6月发布的新季度预测“更加强调通胀至少要在中期达到目标”。欧洲央行副行长路易斯•德金多斯(Luis de Guindos)预计，今年年底欧元区通胀率将高达5%，高于欧洲央行3月份预测的第四季度4%的通胀率。

欧洲央行管理委员会的其他几位成员近日表示，他们将支持在7月份开始一系列加息，而在这个由25名成员组成的利率制定机构中，多数成员目前似乎支持此举。

委员会中最鸽派的成员法比奥•帕内塔(Fabio Panetta)是唯一反对7月加息的人，他更倾向于再等一周，在第二季度增长数据公布后决定。鹰派的奥地利央行行长罗伯特•霍尔兹曼(Robert Holzmann)甚至表示，可以在6月升息，不过他被视为一个例外。

今年1月加入欧洲央行的新成员弗兰克•埃尔德森(Frank Elderson)周三早些时候表示，该行可能会考虑在7月加息，“一如既往地取决于即将到来的数据”。他补充说，如果乌克兰战争不进一步升级，就不会出现欧元区衰退。

欧洲央行立场向鹰派转变，变得与最近上调了利率的美联储(Fed)和英国央行(BoE)更一致。然而，在加息周期方面，欧元区的货币政策制定者仍远远落后于美国和英国的同行，而且是三家央行中唯一将负利率作为政策工具的国家。

拉加德表示，乌克兰战争“降低了增长率，进一步推高了通胀，给货币政策带来了挑战”。

尽管“过去10年的反通胀态势似乎越来越不可能重现”，但她表示，欧元区的消费和投资仍低于疫情爆发前的水平，这意味着欧洲央行的目标将是“正常化”，而不是“收紧”货币政策——这暗示该行只会缓慢加息以继续支持经济活动。

她表示：“首次加息后，正常化过程将是渐进的。”她补充称，“灵活性将是关键”——她指的是欧洲央行讨论的一种可能的“新工具”，旨在通过购买一国债券来应对该国借贷成本的突然飙升。

上周，相对于德国国债，投资者持有意大利国债所需的额外借贷成本上升了2个百分点，这是近两年来的首次，突显出人们的担忧：欧洲央行收紧货币政策，将主要影响债务负担较高的欧元区国家。
interactive.eheadline: Lagarde sends clear signal that ECB will raise rates in July
interactive.elongleadbody: Economists now think first increase in more than a decade is ‘a done deal’
interactive.ebody: Christine Lagarde has signalled she would support raising the European Central Bank’s main interest rate in July, leading economists to declare that the first increase for more than a decade is almost certain to go ahead. The ECB president said in a speech in Slovenia on Wednesday that she expected the bank to stop expanding its balance sheet through bond purchases “early in the third quarter” and to then raise rates “some time” after that, which “could mean a period of only a few weeks”. Lagarde added that “actions that demonstrate our commitment to price stability” would be critical in ensuring businesses’ and households’ expectations of future inflation did not rise any further and test the credibility of the central bank. Eurozone inflation hit a record 7.5 per cent in April — almost four times the central bank’s target of 2 per cent. The remarks are a clear sign that Lagarde supports the growing number of governing council members that have called for a 25 basis point rise to the ECB’s deposit rate at the July 21 policy meeting. The deposit rate is now minus 0.5 per cent and has been in negative territory since 2014, when it was lowered to help fight the region’s debt crisis. Economists have been bringing forward their forecasts of when the central bank will raise rates. Reinhard Cluse at UBS on Wednesday predicted a 25 basis point increase in July would be the first of seven such moves to lift its deposit rate to 1.25 per cent by next year. Frederik Ducrozet, a strategist at Pictet Wealth Management, tweeted that a July rate rise by the ECB seemed “a done deal”. ECB officials are increasingly concerned that the fallout from Russia’s invasion of Ukraine will keep inflation high for longer and embed expectations of rising prices among consumers and companies. Lagarde said the war was “likely to accelerate two ongoing structural changes which, during the transition they entail, could lead to further negative supply shocks and cost pressures.” The ECB’s new quarterly forecasts to be published in June were “increasingly pointing towards inflation being at least on target over the medium term,” she said. Luis de Guindos, vice-president of the ECB, predicted eurozone inflation would be as high as 5 per cent at the end of this year — higher than its forecast in March for inflation of 4 per cent in the fourth quarter of the year. Several other ECB governing council members have spoken out in recent days to say they would support starting a series of rate rises in July and a majority on the 25-member rate-setting body now seems to favour such a move. Fabio Panetta, the most dovish member of the executive board, is the only one to argue against a July rate increase, preferring to wait until second-quarter growth figures are published a week later. Austria’s hawkish central bank governor Robert Holzmann even said it could raise rates in June, though he is seen as an outlier. Frank Elderson, the newest member of the ECB’s executive board who joined in January, said earlier on Wednesday that it could consider raising rates in July “dependent as always on the incoming data”. He added that a eurozone recession was not envisaged, providing the war in Ukraine did not escalate further. The hawkish shift brings the ECB closer in line with the US Federal Reserve and the Bank of England, which both raised rates recently. However, the eurozone’s monetary policymakers still lag far behind their peers in the US and UK in the cycle of raising interest rates and were the only ones of the trio to deploy negative rates as a policy tool. Lagarde said the Ukraine war was “creating a challenge for monetary policy by tempering growth rates and pushing up inflation further”.  While “it looks increasingly unlikely the disinflationary dynamics of the past decade will return”, she said consumption and investment were still below pre-pandemic levels in the eurozone, meaning the ECB would aim to “normalise” rather than “tighten” monetary policy — signalling that it would only raise rates slowly to continue supporting activity.  “After the first rate hike, the normalisation process will be gradual,” she said, adding “flexibility will be key” — a reference to a possible “new instrument” the central bank has discussed to tackle any sudden surge of a country’s borrowing costs by buying its bonds. The additional borrowing costs investors demand to hold Italian debt over that of Germany climbed higher than 2 percentage points last week for the first time in almost two years, underscoring concerns that any ECB tightening of monetary policy will mainly affect eurozone countries with higher debt burdens.

interactive.cheadline: 马斯克称Twitter不会分散他对特斯拉的注意力
interactive.clongleadbody: 自Twitter董事会接受马斯克收购要约以来的两周里，人们担心这位全球首富是否自不量力，再管理一家公司是否会让他力不从心。
interactive.cbody:
收购Twitter会不会是一种危及埃隆•马斯克(Elon Musk)创业帝国的狂妄行为？

自这家社交媒体公司的董事会接受马斯克440亿美元的收购要约以来的两周里，人们担心这位全球首富是否自不量力。人们担心的问题包括：再管理一家公司是否会让他力不从心；抵押或出售他在特斯拉(Tesla)持有的部分巨额个人股权带来的风险；他承诺带给Twitter的“言论自由”绝对主义可能引发的政治反弹。

周二，在英国《金融时报》举办的“汽车未来峰会”(Future of the Car Summit)上，马斯克接受了内容广泛的采访。马斯克认为外界的质疑——在他努力应对电动汽车制造商特斯拉面临的重大问题之际，Twitter是否会对他的整体商业利益造成拖累——毫无必要。

特斯拉面临的问题包括，在严重的全球供应链危机之际管理被马斯克称为史上增长最快的制造企业所带来的压力，以及跨越日益扩大的中美地缘政治鸿沟所带来的压力。

马斯克指出，他习惯于处理短暂而高强度的工作，能够随时将注意力转移到旗下各公司最紧急的问题上。他表示，在出席英国《金融时报》的活动、接受收购Twitter交易达成以来首次采访的两天前，他工作了一通宵外加第二天白天，就是在处理一个紧急问题。

他否认拥有Twitter会增加他目前拥有的其他业务的风险。当被问及他关于Twitter备受争议的计划是否会以某种方式影响特斯拉自身时，他的回答是：“我有信心，我们将能够卖掉所有我们能生产出的汽车。”

这位特斯拉的老板今年就如何应对“需求超过产量达到荒谬程度”的情况进行了详细的讨论。周二，他暗示了一个新想法：暂时停止接受新订单。他说：“我们实际上可能会进行限制——在某段时间后停止接受任何订单。”

此外，拥有Twitter可能会带来复杂的政治考量。马斯克的竞争对手、科技界亿万富翁杰夫•贝索斯(Jeff Bezos)等人提出了一种可能性，即马斯克对上海工厂的依赖可能会让他面临来自中国的压力，要求他审查Twitter。这位经常脾气暴躁的首席执行官对这一说法不屑一顾，毫不迟疑地说：“我没看到有这方面的迹象。”

马斯克一直很乐意跨越其他商界领袖避免的政治断层线。这位特斯拉老板指出，目前上海的封锁措施对特斯拉的命运构成了直接风险。马斯克表示，他与相关人士进行的讨论缓解了他的担忧，这反映出他与中国政府的密切关系。

“最近几天，我与中国政府进行了一些交谈，很明显，封锁正在迅速解除，”他说，语气比他之前质疑加州关闭工厂的命令时更加温和，“所以我认为这在未来几周不会是重大问题。”

在美国四分五裂的政治气候下，他毫不留情地抨击了他所说的Twitter的左翼偏见，并主张废除Twitter对唐纳德•特朗普(Donald Trump)的永久禁令。他声称，他的目标是在政治光谱的两极都树敌。

对于怀疑他个人倾向于支持特朗普的左翼批评者来说，马斯克有不同的话要说。他说，将这位前总统拒之门外并没有压制他的“声音”，反而“放大了他在右翼中的声量”——这使得让他重返更广泛的社交媒体平台变得至关重要。

尽管马斯克直言不讳地抨击了Twitter的过界行为，但在周二承认管理特斯拉的增长面临挑战时，他的语气比最近几次露面要慎重得多。与之前过于乐观的产量预测相比，他降低了预期，称特斯拉最近宣布的到2030年每年生产2000万辆汽车的目标是“抱负”，而不是一个硬性目标。

他还指出，电池原材料的供应是特斯拉实现长期目标的最大障碍之一。当被问及特斯拉是否会收购矿业公司以保证供应时，他明确表示，所有的选择都在考虑范围内：“我们并不是希望收购矿业公司，但如果这是加速（向可持续能源）转型的唯一途径，那么我们会这么做。”

马斯克并不回避支持可能给特斯拉带来重大财务风险的决定——包括推进一项有限形式的自动驾驶技术——如果他认为这将拯救许多人的生命的话。“我们将忍辱负重，”他说，“如果我们相信受伤的概率降低了……但我们也知道，尽管我们做了正确的事情，我们还是会被起诉，我们会做正确的事情，然后被起诉。”

当他谈到Twitter上的言论自由问题时，他的语气变得更加慎重。马斯克之前一直坚持，他将允许在Twitter上发表任何合法言论，但这招致了大量投诉。周二，他说Twitter应该限制那些“对世界具有破坏性”的东西的传播——这话说得很活，为Twitter未来的审查政策留下了大量的主观空间。

在拒绝像对特朗普那样的永久禁令的同时，他首次建议Twitter应该有其他方法来限制破坏性信息的传播——包括“暂停、延迟，或让某条推文不可见或将它限流”。

这些武器已经存在于Twitter的内容审核武器库中，这意味着围绕如何捍卫网络言论自由的鸿沟可能并不像他之前描述的那么大。
interactive.eheadline: Elon Musk downplays fears Twitter deal will jeopardise Tesla focus
interactive.elongleadbody: From navigating geopolitics to corporate risk-taking, billionaire acknowledges the challenges facing his growing empire
interactive.ebody: Could buying Twitter be an act of hubris that jeopardises Elon Musk’s startup empire? In the two weeks since the social media company’s board accepted his $44bn offer, there are concerns that the world’s richest man is biting off more than he can chew. They have ranged from whether he will be stretched too thin in taking on another company, to risks from mortgaging or selling some of his large personal Tesla stake, and worries about a political backlash over the “free speech” abolutism he has promised at Twitter. In a wide-ranging interview at the FT’s Future of the Car Summit on Tuesday, Musk swatted away questions about whether Twitter will weigh on his wider business interests while he grapples with the huge issues confronting electric car maker Tesla. They included the stresses that have come from managing what he described as the fastest-growing manufacturing company in history amid the severe global supply chain crisis and straddling the widening geopolitical gulf between the US and China. Musk pointed to habits already designed to handle brief and intense bursts of work, as his restless focus shifts between his companies’ most pressing problems. He said that two nights before appearing at the FT event to give his first interview since reaching the deal to buy Twitter, he had worked through the night and the next day dealing with one such problem. He rejected the suggestion that owning Twitter would add to the risks at his current businesses. Asked if his controversial plans for the network might rebound somehow on Tesla itself, his response was: “I am confident we will be able to sell all the cars we can make.” The Tesla boss has talked at length this year about dealing with a situation in which “demand is exceeding production to a ridiculous degree”. On Tuesday, he hinted at a new idea: temporarily cutting off new orders. “We’re actually probably going to limit that — just stop taking orders for anything beyond a certain period of time,” he said. Then there are the complicated political calculations that might come from owning Twitter. Rival tech billionaire Jeff Bezos is among those raising the possibility that Musk’s dependence on manufacturing in Shanghai might leave him exposed to pressure from China to censor Twitter. The often irascible chief executive barely blinked as he brushed off the suggestion: “I’ve seen no indication to that effect.”  Musk has been quite happy to step over political fault lines that other business leaders have avoided. The Tesla boss singled out the current Shanghai Covid-19 lockdowns as an immediate risk to Tesla’s fortunes. Illustrating his close relationship with the Chinese government, Musk said he had discussions that eased his concerns. “I’ve had some conversations with the Chinese government in recent days, and it’s clear that the lockdowns are being lifted rapidly,” he said, taking a more moderate tone than he used when challenging a previous plant closure order in California. “So I would not expect this to be a significant issue in the coming weeks.” On the fractured political climate in the US, he pulled no punches in attacking what he claimed was leftwing bias at Twitter and arguing for the reversal of Donald Trump’s permanent ban from the network. His goal, he claimed, was to make enemies at both extremes of the political spectrum. For critics on the left who suspect him of personal pro-Trump bias, Musk had a different message. Shutting the ex-president out did not silence his “voice”, but instead served to “amplify it on the right”, he said — making it essential to bring him back to a broader social media platform. While outspoken in his attack on Twitter’s overreach, Musk on Tuesday projected a far more measured tone than in some recent appearances as he acknowledged the challenges of managing Tesla’s growth. In contrast to previous over-optimistic production forecasts, he tempered expectations, referring to Tesla’s recently stated goal of producing 20mn cars a year by 2030 as an “aspiration” rather than a hard target.  He also singled out availability of raw materials for its batteries as one of the biggest obstacles to Tesla’s long-term goal. Asked if Tesla might even buy a mining company to guarantee supplies, he made it clear that all options are on the table: “It’s not that we wish to buy mining companies, but if that’s the only way to accelerate the transition [to sustainable energy], then we will.” Musk did not shy away from backing decisions that could entail big financial risks for Tesla, including going ahead with a limited form of self-driving technology if he thought it would save many lives. “We’re just going to take the heat,” he said. “If we believe that the probability of injury is reduced . . . but we also know that we’re going to be sued despite doing the right thing, we will do the right thing and get sued.” A more measured tone crept in as he discussed free speech on Twitter. Musk’s insistence until now that he would allow any speech on Twitter as long as it is legal has brought a storm of complaints. On Tuesday, he said Twitter should limit the spread of things that are “destructive to the world” — a loose term that left room for plenty of subjectivity in Twitter’s future moderation policy.  While rejecting permanent bans like the one on Trump, he suggested for the first time that Twitter should have other ways to limit the spread of damaging information — including “a timeout, a temporary suspension, or that particular tweet should be made invisible or have very limited traction”. Those weapons already exist in Twitter’s content moderation arsenal, implying that the gulf over how to defend free speech online may not be as wide as he has previously painted it.

interactive.cheadline: 丰田警告原材料价格“空前”上涨
interactive.clongleadbody: 由于原材料和物流成本空前上涨，丰田预计本财年营业利润可能下降20%。
interactive.cbody:
丰田(Toyota)警告称，由于新冠疫情导致供应中断，能源成本不断上升，原材料价格上涨一倍，该公司今年的利润可能下降五分之一。

标准普尔全球市场情报(S&P Global Market Intelligence)的数据显示，丰田预测本财年营业利润为2.4万亿日元（合10亿美元），远低于分析师3.3万亿日元的预测。在2021-2022财年，该公司营业利润创下日本企业纪录。

这家全球最大汽车制造商预计营业利润将下降20%，导致其股价周三下跌4.4%。

该集团旗下拥有子公司大发(Daihatsu)和日野(Hino)，预计本财年将销售1070万辆汽车，高于去年的1030万辆。

丰田会计小组首席官员Masahiro Yamamoto说：“由于材料和物流成本空前上涨，预计营业利润将会下降。不过，我们将继续进行未来的投资。”

高管们表示，日元走弱和汽车销量高涨不太可能抵消原材料和物流成本的大幅上升。原材料和物流成本预计将达到1.45万亿日元。这将是去年成本的两倍多，而去年的成本也达到了历史新高。

丰田表示，今年的成本有一半来自海外业务，其余将来自日本。该公司还表示，将努力减少某些材料的使用，或代之以更便宜的材料。

尽管成本上升，但丰田表示很难提高产品价格。首席沟通官Jun Nagata说：“仅仅因为材料成本上涨就提高成品价格是具有挑战性的。我们的基本立场是，在仔细研究每个地区的基础上做出决定。”

分析师表示，丰田有上调预期的空间，因为该公司假定日元兑美元汇率为1美元兑115日元，与目前1美元兑130日元的汇率对比鲜明。

然而，保守的前景仍令投资者感到不安，因为在全球疫情期间，这家日本汽车制造商通过严格削减成本来抵消供应链中断和工厂关闭的影响，表现优于竞争对手。

行业分析师Takaki Nakanishi说：“丰田目前还不是提出乐观预测的阶段。”他指的是，该集团旗下公司存在造假丑闻，上一财年的产量预测一再被下调。

除了钢铁和铝价格上涨外，Nakanishi表示，丰田面临的挑战是日本消费者对价格上涨很敏感。

丰田公布第四季度营业利润为4630亿日元，同比下降33%。营收达到8.1万亿日元，增长6%。
interactive.eheadline: Toyota warns of ‘unprecedented’ rise in raw material prices
interactive.elongleadbody: World’s largest carmaker forecasts 20% drop in annual operating profit
interactive.ebody: Toyota warned its profits could fall by a fifth this year because of rising energy costs and a doubling in raw material prices following coronavirus pandemic-related disruptions to supplies. Toyota’s projection of ¥2.4tn ($1bn) operating profit for this financial year was well below analyst forecasts of ¥3.3tn, according to S&P Global Market Intelligence. In the 2021-2022 financial year, it delivered a record operating profit for a Japanese company. The forecast 20 per cent drop in operating profits by the world’s largest carmaker sent its shares down 4.4 per cent on Wednesday. The group, which includes Toyota’s Daihatsu and Hino subsidiaries, expects to sell 10.7mn vehicles this financial year, compared with 10.3mn units last year. “We expect a decrease in our operating income due to unprecedented increases in materials and logistics costs. However, we will continue with our future investments,” said Masahiro Yamamoto, chief officer of Toyota’s accounting group. Executives said the weaker yen and high vehicle sales were unlikely to offset a steep rise in raw material and logistics costs, which are expected to hit ¥1.45tn. This would more than double last year’s costs, which also reached an all-time high. Half of this year’s costs are from Toyota’s overseas business, while the rest would come from Japan, the company said, adding it would promote efforts to reduce the use of some materials or replace them with cheaper ones. Despite the rising costs, Toyota said it was difficult to increase the price of products. “It is challenging to raise the price of the finished products just because material costs have gone up. Our basic stance is to make decisions based on a careful look at each region,” said Jun Nagata, chief communication officer. Analysts said there was room for Toyota to raise its forecast since the company assumed an exchange rate of ¥115 against the dollar, a sharp contrast to today’s ¥130 rate. However, the conservative outlook still unnerved investors as the Japanese carmaker had outperformed rivals throughout the global pandemic by using stringent cost cuts to offset supply chain disruptions and plant closures. “Toyota is not right now in the phase to come up with a bullish forecast,” said Takaki Nakanishi, an industry analyst, pointing to falsification scandals in the carmaker’s group companies and repeated downgrades of production projections last fiscal year. On top of the rise in steel and aluminium prices, Nakanishi said the challenge for Toyota was that Japanese consumers were sensitive to price increases. Toyota posted an operating profit of ¥463bn for the fourth quarter, down 33 per cent year on year. Its revenue reached ¥8.1tn, up 6 per cent.

interactive.cheadline: 4月份美国通胀率预计将徘徊在40年高点附近
interactive.clongleadbody: 预计4月份美国CPI将同比上涨8.1%。拜登周二强调，抗击通胀是他的政府面临的“最大经济挑战”。
interactive.cbody:
尽管4月份美国消费者价格指数(CPI)的上涨速度略有放缓，但预计仍将保持在40年来的最高水平，这突显出美联储遏制通胀的紧迫性。

根据彭博社(Bloomberg)编制的一份共识预测，上月CPI将同比上涨8.1%，略低于3月份8.5%的涨幅。

预计物价环比上涨0.2%，低于3月份1.2%的涨幅。俄罗斯入侵乌克兰导致的能源和食品价格飙升推动了3月份的涨幅。

然而，剔除食品和能源等波动性较大的项目，预计核心CPI月度涨幅将小幅上升0.1个百分点，至0.4%。这将相当于同比上涨6%。

美国劳工统计局(Bureau of Labor Statistics)将于美国东部时间上午8点30分发布这一数据，可能标志着新冠大流行时期的通胀飙升开始见顶。通胀是由火热的消费者需求和严重的供应链瓶颈造成的。

经济学家普遍预计，随着乌克兰战争的直接影响减弱，CPI上涨速度将从目前的水平进一步放缓。未来几个月，通胀同比数据也应该会开始下降，因为要与去年创下的极高水平进行比较。

然而，有证据表明，价格压力不再仅限于最受疫情相关中断影响的行业，而是一种影响所有行业的广泛趋势，这使人们担心，通胀正成为一个持久的问题。

美国总统乔•拜登(Joe Biden)周二强调，抗击通胀是他的政府面临的“最大经济挑战”。他对美联储遏制通胀的努力表示支持。

美联储加大了遏制物价压力的努力，本月首次加息50个基点。预计6月和7月将进一步加息，甚至可能在9月还要加息，联邦基金利率预计将在年底前达到2.7%。

美联储削减其9万亿美元资产负债表的行动也将从6月开始，这是其为给经济降温的两个杠杆中的第二个。

投资者面临的关键问题是，美国央行能否在不引发衰退的情况下降低通胀。纽约联储(New York Fed)主席约翰•威廉姆斯(John Williams)本周表示，实现软着陆的挑战将是艰巨的，但“并非不可克服”。

最近几天，金融市场剧烈震荡，股市大幅下挫，美国借贷成本走高。10年期美国国债收益率目前徘徊在3%左右，约为今年初1.5%的两倍。
interactive.eheadline: US inflation expected to hover near four-decade high despite moderation
interactive.elongleadbody: CPI forecast to have risen at annual pace of 8.1% in April as Fed readies for more aggressive tightening
interactive.ebody: The breakneck pace of US consumer price increases is expected to have remained at a four-decade high in April despite moderating slightly, underscoring the urgency of the Federal Reserve’s push to stamp out inflation. According to a consensus forecast compiled by Bloomberg, the consumer price index is set to have risen at an annual pace of 8.1 per cent last month, marginally lower than the 8.5 per cent increase recorded in March. Prices are predicted to have climbed 0.2 per cent from the previous month, slower than the 1.2 per cent rise recorded in March that was fuelled by soaring energy and food costs tied to Russia’s invasion of Ukraine. Stripping out volatile items like food and energy, however, the monthly rise in core CPI is expected to have increased marginally, up 0.1 of a percentage point to 0.4 per cent. On an annual basis, that would amount to a 6 per cent increase. The data, to be published by the Bureau of Labor Statistics at 8:30am Eastern Time, could signal the beginning of a peak in the coronavirus pandemic-era inflation surge caused by red-hot consumer demand coupled with severe supply chain bottlenecks. Economists broadly expect the pace of consumer price growth to moderate further from these levels as the immediate effects of the war in Ukraine abate. The headline annual inflation reading should also start to fall in the coming months as it starts being compared to the very elevated levels logged last year. However, evidence that price pressures are no longer a phenomenon exclusive to sectors most affected by pandemic-related disruptions — but rather a broad-based trend affecting all sectors — has stoked concerns that inflation is becoming a persistent problem. US president Joe Biden on Tuesday stressed that fighting inflation was his administration’s “top economic challenge” as he voiced support for the Fed’s efforts to tame inflation. The Fed has ramped up its efforts to contain price pressures, implementing its first half-point rate rise in more than two decades this month. Further such increases are expected in June and July, and potentially even September, with the federal funds rate expected to reach 2.7 per cent by the end of the year. The Fed’s reduction of its $9tn balance sheet will also commence in June, the second of two levers the Fed is using to cool down the economy. The key question for investors is whether the US central bank can bring down inflation without causing a recession. John Williams, the president of the New York Fed, said this week the challenge of engineering a soft landing would be difficult but “not insurmountable”.  Financial markets have gyrated wildly in recent days, with equity markets registering steep losses and US borrowing cost marching higher. The 10-year Treasury yield now hovers around 3 per cent, roughly double its 1.5 per cent level at the start of the year.

interactive.cheadline: 约翰逊称准备撕毁《北爱尔兰议定书》
interactive.clongleadbody: 此举无视欧盟各国政府和布鲁塞尔方面有关不要采取单边行动的长期呼吁，令英国与欧盟发生冲突。
interactive.cbody:
英国首相鲍里斯•约翰逊(Boris Johnson)政府与欧盟(EU)发生冲突。此前，英国政府表示有意下周宣布关于撕毁英国退欧后与北爱尔兰贸易安排的计划。 约翰逊周二对爱尔兰总理米歇尔•马丁(Micheál Martin)表示，目前与欧盟的协议“以当前形式是不可持续的”，无视欧盟各国政府和布鲁塞尔方面有关不要采取单边行动的长期呼吁。 英国政府的两名高级内部人士表示，英国准备最早于下周宣布立法，废除《北爱尔兰议定书》中的部分内容，“除非欧盟彻底改变其做法”。此举可能被视为英国与欧盟之间的紧张关系出现重大升级。 面对英国的威胁，布鲁塞尔方面和欧盟主要国家立即发出警告，称欧盟无意就协议基本内容重新谈判。根据该协议，北爱尔兰必须遵守欧盟的货物贸易规则，在爱尔兰海(Irish Sea)划定了一条边界。 德国总理奥拉夫•朔尔茨(Olaf Scholz)表示，任何破坏《北爱尔兰议定书》的单边行动都将产生超越欧盟-英国关系的影响。 他说：“任何人都不应单方面取消、破坏或以任何方式攻击我们共同达成的协议。”他与比利时外长亚历山大•德克罗(Alexander De Croo)一道发表讲话，德克罗重申了欧盟的警告，即英国的单边行动可能最终导致英国与欧盟爆发贸易战。 德克罗说：“我们的信息很明确：不要这样做……如果这个议定书被废除，那么我认为整个体系也会被废除。我看不到任何其他解决方案。” 在布鲁塞尔，欧盟委员会副主席马罗什•谢夫乔维奇(Maroš Šefčovič)驳斥了约翰逊关于该议定书需要修改或废除的观点。 他周二在一份声明中说：“该议定书是（英国退欧）协议的基石，是一项国际协议。重新谈判不是一个选项。欧盟在这一立场上是一致的，” 上周北爱尔兰议会选举结束后，该地区亲英国的民主统一党(Democratic Unionist party)拒绝在与《北爱尔兰议定书》有关的问题得到解决之前加入北爱尔兰权力分享行政机构，这重新点燃了解决有关该议定书长期分歧的压力。 民主统一党表示，该议定书中的贸易安排正在破坏该地区在英国的地位，必须废除。由于北爱尔兰没有一个充分运作的权力下放行政机构，关于行政机构组建的拉锯战可能会导致北爱尔兰发生数月的政治动荡。 随着民族主义政党新芬党(Sinn Féin)首次成为该地区最大政党，政治紧张局势进一步加剧。 在与爱尔兰总理的通话中，约翰逊告诉爱尔兰领导人马丁，《北爱尔兰议定书》的形势“现在非常严重”，正在破坏1998年的《耶稣受难日协议》，该协议在经历了30年的冲突后确保了该地区的和平。

我们一直倾向于通过谈判解决问题，但如果找不到解决方案，（我们）也不会回避采取行动稳定北爱尔兰局势。

英国外交大臣利兹•特拉斯
约翰逊对马丁表示，英国的“多次努力”未能成功让布鲁塞尔采取必要行动，“如果无法找到解决方案，英国政府将采取行动，保护北爱尔兰的和平与政治稳定”。 马丁呼吁约翰逊专注于与欧盟合作，解决“议定书实施和运行过程中产生的实际问题”。爱尔兰是《耶稣受难日协议》的共同保证人。 他在爱尔兰议会Dáil上说：“现在需要的是对欧盟提供的这种努力和诚意给予适当的回报。” 但爱尔兰官员表达了一种似曾相识的感觉，尽管提议的细节仍不清楚。其中一人说：“我们过去经历过许多次。” 当被问及欧盟是否会妥协时，爱尔兰欧洲事务部长托马斯•伯恩(Thomas Byrne)周二晚间对RTÉ电视台表示，该议定书本身就是妥协。“欧盟委员会提议减少对北爱尔兰检查。 “他（谢夫乔维奇）想要的是英国的建设性讨论。他说议定书本身不会有任何变化，但有一个巨大的机会可以在议定书内进行调整，而英国到目前为止还没有抓住这些机会。” 英国正在起草一项立法，允许英国放弃议定书中涉及贸易和补贴政策的关键部分。 英国官员表示，拟议中的立法（可能需要数月时间才能成为法律）的重点将是“分解”运往北爱尔兰和运往爱尔兰共和国的货物。 来自新芬党的有望成为该地区首席大臣的米歇尔•奥尼尔(Michelle O’neill)周二在与约翰逊交谈后在Twitter上写道，“这里的民众不能成为英国政府与欧盟斗鸡游戏中的棋子”。 英国政府高级内部人士表示，外交大臣利兹•特拉斯(Liz Truss)预计将在“未来几天”与谢夫乔维奇讨论该协议。两人最后一次通话是在12天前。 然而，特拉斯周二晚间发表声明警告称，欧盟提出的放宽《北爱尔兰议定书》实施的建议，实际上可能会“恶化”该协议，这明显表明英国决心就贸易安排问题与欧盟对抗。 她说：“欧盟目前的提议未能妥善解决影响北爱尔兰的实际问题，在某些情况下会让我们倒退。”她补充称，该协议扰乱了贸易，如今“对和平与稳定构成了威胁”。 她补充说：“我们一直倾向于通过谈判解决问题，但如果找不到解决方案，（我们）也不会回避采取行动稳定北爱尔兰局势。” 欧盟外交消息人士预测，英国最近的干预似乎是故意挑衅，布鲁塞尔方面将“非常难以接受”。 安迪•邦兹(Andy Bounds)布鲁塞尔补充报道
interactive.eheadline: Boris Johnson signals readiness to scrap Northern Ireland’s post-Brexit trading deal
interactive.elongleadbody: Move puts UK on collision course with EU, whose leaders warn PM not to act unilaterally
interactive.ebody:
Boris Johnson’s government is on a collision course with the EU after signalling its intention to announce plans next week to tear up post-Brexit trading arrangements for Northern Ireland. The UK prime minister told his Irish counterpart Micheál Martin on Tuesday that the current agreement with the EU was “not sustainable in its current form”, ignoring longstanding appeals from EU capitals and Brussels not to take unilateral action. In what risks being seen as a major escalation of tensions between London and Brussels, two senior government insiders said the UK was preparing to announce legislation to rescind elements of the Northern Ireland protocol as soon as next week “unless the EU radically changes its approach”. The UK threat was met with immediate warnings from Brussels and major EU capitals that the EU had no intention of renegotiating the fundamentals of the agreement, which leaves Northern Ireland following EU rules for trading in goods, creating a border in the Irish Sea. German chancellor Olaf Scholz said any unilateral move to unravel the protocol would have an effect beyond EU-UK relations. “No one should unilaterally cancel, break or in any way attack the settlement we have agreed together,” he said, speaking alongside his Belgian counterpart, Alexander De Croo, who restated EU warnings that unilateral UK action could ultimately lead to a trade war between London and Brussels. “Our message is quite clear: Don’t touch this . . . If that agreement would be revoked, then I would think that the whole system will be revoked. I would not see any other solution,” De Croo said. In Brussels, Maroš Šefčovič, the European Commission vice-president, rejected Johnson’s arguments that the protocol needed to be altered, or scrapped. “The protocol, as a cornerstone of the [Brexit] withdrawal agreement, is an international agreement. Its renegotiation is not an option. The European Union is united in this position,” he said in a statement on Tuesday. The pressure to resolve longstanding differences over the protocol has been reignited by the refusal of the region’s pro-UK Democratic Unionist party to enter a power-sharing executive in Northern Ireland following last week’s regional assembly elections until the issues over the protocol are addressed. The DUP says the trade arrangements in the protocol are undermining the region’s place within the UK and must be scrapped. The tug of war over the formation of an executive raises the prospect of months of political limbo, without a fully functioning devolved executive in Northern Ireland. The political tension has been heightened by the nationalist party Sinn Féin emerging as the biggest party in the region for the first time. In his call with Ireland’s taoiseach, Johnson told Irish leader Martin that the situation with the protocol was “now very serious” and was undermining the 1998 Good Friday Agreement which secured peace in the region after three decades of conflict.

Our preference has always been for a negotiated solution but [we] will not shy away from taking action to stabilise the situation in Northern Ireland if solutions cannot be found

Liz Truss, UK foreign secretary
The prime minister, Downing Street said to Martin that the UK’s “repeated efforts” had not succeeded in securing necessary moves from Brussels and that “the UK government would take action to protect peace and political stability in Northern Ireland if solutions could not be found”. Martin appealed to Johnson to focus on working with the EU on “the practical issues arising from the implementation and operation of the protocol”. Ireland is a co-guarantor of the Good Friday Agreement. “What is required now is a proper reciprocation of that effort and good faith offered by the European Union,” he said in the Dáil, Ireland’s parliament. But Irish officials expressed a feeling of déjà vu, even though details of the proposals remained unclear. “We’ve been here so many times in the past,” said one. Asked if the EU would compromise, Thomas Byrne, Irish minister for European affairs, told RTÉ television on Tuesday evening that the protocol itself was the compromise. “The European Commission has proposals on the table to reduce the checks going into Northern Ireland. “What he [Šefčovič] wants is constructive discussion from the British. He said there will be no changes to the protocol document itself but there is a huge opportunity to make adjustments within the protocol and the British so far haven’t grasped those opportunities.” London is drafting legislation that would allow the UK to abandon key sections of the protocol that cover trade and subsidy policy. The focus of the proposed legislation, which could take many months to become law, would be to “disaggregate” goods destined for Northern Ireland and those heading to the Republic of Ireland, according to UK officials. Michelle O’Neill, the region’s first minister-in-waiting from Sinn Féin, wrote on Twitter after speaking with Johnson on Tuesday that “the public here can’t be a pawn in the British government’s game of chicken with the EU”. Senior UK government insiders said that foreign secretary Liz Truss was expected to speak to Šefčovič “in the coming days” about the protocol. The pair last spoke 12 days ago. However, in a clear sign of the UK’s determination to confront the EU over trading arrangements, Truss released a statement on Tuesday night warning that EU proposals to ease the implementation of the protocol could actually “worsen” the deal. “The current EU proposals fail to properly address the real issues affecting Northern Ireland and in some cases would take us backward,” she said, adding that the protocol had disrupted trade and now posed “a threat to peace and stability”. She added: “Our preference has always been for a negotiated solution but [we] will not shy away from taking action to stabilise the situation in Northern Ireland if solutions cannot be found.” EU diplomatic sources predicted that the latest UK intervention appeared deliberately provocative and would be “very poorly received” in Brussels. Additional reporting by Andy Bounds in Brussels

interactive.cheadline: 新西兰将重新开放边境并放松高技术移民规定
interactive.clongleadbody: 新西兰将提前两个月重新开放边境，并为某些行业推出了移民居留权快速通道。
interactive.cbody:
新西兰将提前两个月重新开放边境，并放松移民规定，以吸引熟练劳工，这将结束新西兰在新冠疫情期间两年多的严格入境限制。

杰辛达•阿德恩(Jacinda Ardern)政府在这场健康危机的大部分时间里采取了“清零”战略，包括严厉封锁和关闭边境。

新西兰工党(Labour party)政府周三表示，将从7月31日起取消限制，放松医疗、工程和技术等特定行业的劳工入境要求，并提供一条更快的居留权获取途径。

海外学生的入境要求也将被放松。

政府补充说，但对非熟练劳工的规定将继续实施，并表示该国不应回到疫情前依赖低成本移民劳动力的那种情况。

这位新西兰总理表示，该国“对商业完全开放”。

阿德恩说：“这对家庭、企业和我们的移民社区来说都是好消息。”她补充说，这将在春夏旅游旺季之前提供“确定性”。

总理还宣布了一份新的“绿色名单”，包括85个被证明很难填补的高技能职位，并将2万份工作签证延期。政府表示，希望雇佣海外技术劳工的新西兰企业遇到的官僚主义将会减少，签证审批程序也将简化。

但新西兰移民事务部长克里斯•法福伊(Kris Faafoi)表示，该国“不可能回到疫情前的趋势，即过度依赖越来越多的低技能劳工，导致对移民的剥削加剧”。

“我们的计划是在国内培养技能。”他说。

新西兰反对党国家党(National party)移民事务发言人埃里卡•斯坦福(Erica Stanford)表示，政府行动不够迅速，没有听取企业改善低技能劳工招聘的要求。

她对《新西兰先驱报》(New Zealand Herald)表示：“新西兰商界一直在期待有关如何更快把劳工招聘进来的公告，但他们没有得到这个消息。”

在做出放松限制的决定之前，新西兰央行(Reserve Bank of New Zealand)上月将利率上调0.5个百分点，至1.5%，这是22年来最大幅度的单次加息。

一周后，新西兰截至3月份的年度通货膨胀率达到6.9%，这是自1990年以来的最大涨幅，促使奥克兰商会敦促政府”在扼杀移民的设置方面采取行动，以便雇主能够引进技能以满足需求并建立生产率和竞争力"。该国的失业率仅为3.2％。
interactive.eheadline: New Zealand to reopen borders and ease high-skilled immigration rules
interactive.elongleadbody: Jacinda Ardern lifts entry requirements early and launches fast-track residency for certain sectors
interactive.ebody: New Zealand will reopen its borders two months ahead of schedule and ease immigration rules to lure skilled workers, ending more than two years of severe entry restrictions during the coronavirus pandemic. Jacinda Ardern’s government has operated a “zero-Covid” strategy for much of the health crisis that has included harsh lockdowns and a closed border. The Labour party government said on Wednesday that it would lift restrictions from July 31, easing entry for workers in certain sectors including healthcare, engineering and tech, and provide a faster route to residency. Entry requirements for overseas students will also be eased. But rules for unskilled workers will remain in place, the government added, saying the country should not return to its pre-pandemic reliance on low-cost migrant labour. The prime minister said the country was “fully open for business”. “This will be welcome news for families, businesses and our migrant communities,” Ardern said, adding that it would provide “certainty” ahead of the peak spring and summer tourism seasons. The prime minister also announced a new “Green List” of 85 high-skilled roles that have proved hard to fill and the extension of 20,000 work visas. New Zealand businesses that want to hire skilled overseas workers will be subject to less bureaucracy and the visa approval process will be streamlined, the government said. But immigration minister Kris Faafoi said the country could “not return to pre-pandemic trends that saw us overly reliant on growing numbers of lower-skilled workers and resulted in the increased exploitation of migrants”. “Our plan is to grow skills at home,” he said. Erica Stanford, immigration spokesperson for the opposition National party, said the government was not acting quickly enough and had not listened to business demands to improve recruitment of low-skilled workers. “Business New Zealand had been expecting an announcement about how to get workers in more quickly and they did not get that,” she told the New Zealand Herald newspaper. The decision to ease restrictions came after the Reserve Bank of New Zealand lifted interest rates 0.5 percentage points to 1.5 per cent last month, the highest single increase in 22 years. A week later, inflation for the year to March hit 6.9 per cent, the biggest rise since 1990, prompting the Auckland Business Chamber to urge the government “to move on the stifling immigration settings so employers can bring in the skills to meet demand and build productivity and competitiveness”. Unemployment in the country is just 3.2 per cent.

interactive.cheadline: 斯里兰卡总统敦促民众保持冷静
interactive.clongleadbody: 斯里兰卡经济危机引发暴力示威，国家紧急状态已被延长。
interactive.cbody:
多日来的暴乱使斯里兰卡政府处于崩溃的边缘，该国总统戈塔巴亚•拉贾帕克萨(Gotabaya Rajapaksa)呼吁民众保持冷静。军队在全国范围内实施宵禁，并威胁要击毙抢劫者。

近几周来，该岛国民众的抗议活动愈演愈烈，他们要求拉贾帕克萨辞职，原因是该国经济危机导致日常必需品严重短缺，通胀达到两位数，并导致政府接近违约。

在一轮暴力动乱导致内阁解体后，戈塔巴亚的哥哥马欣达•拉贾帕克萨(Mahinda Rajapaksa)周一辞去总理职务。马欣达认为，他的辞职在维持戈塔巴亚统治的同时，将为跨党派政府铺平道路，以平息事态。

但总统无法组建新政府，许多反对派领导人不愿与他合作，抗议者再次呼吁他辞职。

试图与国际货币基金组织(IMF)、世界银行(WB)和其他机构谈判经济援助的拉贾帕克萨政府因为没有内阁而陷入了僵局。

“现在是全体斯里兰卡人齐心协力克服经济、社会和政治挑战的时候。”拉贾帕克萨周三在Twitter上写道，“我敦促所有斯里兰卡人拒绝将你们推向种族和宗教不和谐境地的颠覆企图。”

军队已被部署执行全国宵禁（已延长至周四），而且被命令对抢劫者开枪。

本周，至少有8人在亲政府和反政府抗议者之间的暴力冲突中丧生，其中包括一名拉贾帕克萨家族领导的斯里兰卡执政党人民阵线党(Podujana Peramuna)的议员。周二，一名高级警官也在首都科伦坡遭到暴徒袭击。

在过去二十年的大部分时间里，拉贾帕克萨家族一直控制着斯里兰卡的政治。马欣达在2005年至2015年担任总统期间，通过一场残酷的军事行动镇压了泰米尔分离主义叛军，结束了长达30年的内战。

在野四年之后，戈塔巴亚于2019年当选总统，该家族重新掌权。但是，一系列减税措施和疫情期间关键旅游收入的损失使这个岛国陷入了债务危机，无法为总计超过500亿美元的外债进行再融资。

斯里兰卡的外汇储备已降至5000万美元，这使得该国无法进口足够的食品、药品和燃料来满足国民需求。

当局已寻求印度和中国等国以及多边贷款机构的救助。

国际货币基金组织表示，正在继续与斯里兰卡进行技术讨论，但如果没有任命新内阁，他们将无法推进贷款谈判。根据向当地媒体发布的一份声明，该基金对“日益加剧的社会紧张和暴力”表示担忧。
interactive.eheadline: Sri Lanka president urges calm as anti-government protests intensify
interactive.elongleadbody: National emergency extended after violent demonstrations over economic crisis
interactive.ebody: Sri Lanka’s president Gotabaya Rajapaksa called for calm after days of violent unrest that have left his government on the brink of collapse, with the army enforcing a nationwide curfew and threatening to shoot looters. The island has faced intensifying protests in recent weeks calling on Rajapaksa to resign over an economic crisis that has led to severe shortages of everyday essentials and double-digit inflation and pushed the government close to default. Mahinda Rajapaksa, Gotabaya’s elder brother, stepped down as prime minister on Monday after a wave of violence, triggering the dissolution of the cabinet. Mahinda argued that his resignation would pave the way for a cross-party government to restore calm while keeping Gotabaya in power. But the president has been unable to form a new government, with many opposition leaders unwilling to work with him and protesters reiterating calls on him to quit. The lack of a cabinet has left Rajapaksa’s government in a state of limbo as it tries to negotiate economic bailouts with the IMF, World Bank and others. “This is the time for all Sri Lankans to join hands as one, to overcome the economic, social and political challenges,” Rajapaksa wrote on Twitter on Wednesday. “I urge all Sri Lankans to reject the subversive attempts to push you towards racial and religious disharmony.” The army, which has been deployed to enforce a nationwide curfew that has been extended to Thursday, was ordered to shoot looters on sight. At least eight people were killed in violence between pro- and anti-government protesters this week, including a lawmaker from the Rajapaksa family’s ruling Sri Lanka Podujana Peramuna party. A senior police official was also attacked by a mob in the capital Colombo on Tuesday. The Rajapaksa family has dominated Sri Lankan politics for most of the past two decades. Mahinda oversaw the end of a three-decade civil war when he was president between 2005 and 2015 with a brutal military campaign to crush Tamil separatist rebels. After four years in opposition, the family returned to power in 2019 with Gotabaya’s election as leader. But a series of tax cuts and the loss of crucial tourism revenues during the pandemic plunged the island into a debt crisis, leaving it unable to refinance foreign debt totalling more than $50bn. Sri Lanka’s foreign currency reserves have fallen to as low as $50mn, leaving it unable to import enough food, medicine and fuel for its population. Authorities have sought bailouts from countries including India and China as well as multilateral lenders. The IMF said it was continuing technical discussions with Sri Lanka, though it will be unable to advance talks for a loan without the appointment of a new cabinet. The fund expressed concern over “rising social tensions and violence”, according to a statement shared with local media.
